headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Systems Fourth Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to intr
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Systems Fourth Quarter 2015 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to introduce Mr. Eduardo Fleites, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kyle. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Presentation. Participating on the call will be Bob Calderoni, Executive Chairman; President and Chief Executive Officer; and
componenttext:
Thank you, Kyle. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Presentation. Participating on the call will be Bob Calderoni, Executive Chairman; President and Chief Executive Officer; and David Henshall, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer. This call is being webcast on Citrix Systems Investor Relations website. The webcast will be posted immediately following the call.
Before we begin, I want to state that we have posted product specification and historical revenue trends related to our product groupings to our Investor Relations website. I'd like to remind you that today's conversation will contain forward-looking statements made under the Safe Harbor provision of the U.S. securities law. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Obviously, these risks could cause actual results to differ from those anticipated. Additional information concerning these and other factors is highlighted in today's press release and in the company's filings with the SEC. Copies are available from the SEC or on the company's Investor Relations website.
Furthermore, we will discuss various non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC's Reg G. A reconciliation of the differences between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures discussed on today's call can be found at the end of today's press release and on the Investor Relations page of our website. Now I'd like to turn it over to David Henschel, our Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer. David?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us today. We're making great progress on the operational initiatives that we launched last year. At a high level, the most important activity has really been simplifying our strategic focus, driving both
componenttext:
Thank you, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us today. We're making great progress on the operational initiatives that we launched last year. At a high level, the most important activity has really been simplifying our strategic focus, driving both portfolio optimization and clarity in terms of what's most important to the company, our partners and our customers. 
Our results for Q4 reflect the progress the team has made in absorbing and adjusting to these initiatives cost structure work, work and leadership evolution and changes to our field in general strategy. We'll continue to focus our energy towards our core strategy to secure delivery of apps and data, really setting the company up for even better results of efficiency and growth as we look forward. As you saw from the release today, total revenue was up 6% year-on-year in Q4 with product license up 5%. Adjusted operating margins jump to 32%, adjusted EPS was $1.66 share, up 50%, and we generated $282 million in cash flow from ops. In total, we closed 86 $1-million-plus transactions across products and services. The Americas region booked the majority of these with 60 and EMEA had 23. 
There's a couple of points that are worth noting in that the average value of these large deals increased significantly year-on-year in both the U.S. and EMEA. And at a product level, I think, we saw a really good balance across the portfolio. Roughly 1/3 were made up of virtualization and mobile products, 1/3 from networking, 20% from the full Workspace Suite and the remainder coming from subscription and services. The combination of these large transactions plus strong renewals and other businesses and the ongoing migration to higher value maintenance offerings boosted total deferred revenue by $154 million sequentially. On an annual basis, short-term deferred is up 4%, while multi-year is up 16%. 
From a geo perspective, when you exclude the SaaS businesses, the Americas was really the big driver in the quarter with revenue up 11%. EMEA was flat but results in APAC declined by 13% year-on-year. Since our restructuring last year occurred earlier in the U.S. versus the other geos, the U.S. teams have had much more time to stabilize and adopt to the new structure, really a key contributor in performance in Q4. 
Next, let's take a look at the Q4 results within our 3 primary businesses. Our Workspace Services business grew 4% year-on-year to $352 million, including license growth of 1%, continuing the steady improvement and results we've seen over the past 5 quarters. Really more than any other of our businesses, Workspace Services should benefit the work we're doing to simplify focus and strategy and as we've reviewed before, there's a number of very specific initiatives that we're driving to accelerate growth in this area through innovation, virtualization and the aggregation of our unique assets. We've built the market-leading products that allows the secure delivery of the world's most important applications, including Windows, Web, mobile and customer line of business apps. Plus, we built the integrations in your enterprise file sharing and networking solutions that together creates really a powerful mobility system for our customers, as well as market differentiation. 
In the quarter of the Workspace Suite, which is our comprehensive solution for app and data delivery, contributed nearly 20% of license revenue for this group and this compares to just 9% a year ago. Additionally, we continue to grow our CSP business where partners primarily utilize XenApp to deliver subscription-based offerings to their customers. This quarter's CSP revenue grew over 30% year-on-year and closed the full year at just over $55 million of total recognized revenue. So we're delivering a complete mobility solution, allowing customers of all sizes to bridge between the worlds of Windows and mobility, on-premise or service-based, and we do it really all with the customers-centric experience that only Citrix can provide. 
Next, looking at the Delivery Networking, total revenue increased 13% in the quarter to $220  including license growth of 10%. The strength in this business was driven by NetScaler. Offsetting this was a significant decline by mobile business as we transition away from that product line. But focusing on NetScaler, it's important to remind everybody that the business here is essentially made up of 3 segments: the tax sales, enterprise ADC and strategic service providers. Tax sales, where customers are purchasing networking and Workspace Services together as part of a larger Citrix solution, represented about 20% of the NetScaler mix in Q4. There were over 800 of these transactions and this compares with just 700 a year ago. Enterprise ADC was about 1/3 of the mix growing modestly and of the service provider segment contributed more than 40% of license and similar to what we discussed in Q3, we saw strong demand across the main major service cloud providers. All in, we sold over 2,500 unique customers in the period with 36% being new customers. 
Finally, in our SaaS-based solutions, we delivered revenue of $194 million, up 15% in the quarter. The Communications Cloud remains the largest part of this business contributing over 60% of the mix and growing about 19% year-on-year. In the workflow area, our data platform, ShareFile, was up nearly 30% in subscription-based revenue with the majority of this growth coming across regulated verticals. Our focus on improving retention rates of our active user base has really helped Net New Business increase significantly year-over-year. This has been driven by changes across products, packaging, as well as customer organization. Back in November, we announced the intention to spend our GoTo family of products in the second half of this year. And say that these plans remain well on track and on the coming quarters real provide much more visibility into this business, as well as into the ShareFile business that will remain part of Citrix going forward. 
So turning to operations. We have delivered a rapid increase in margins over the past few quarters, really despite funding incremental investments in our higher growth businesses. As we discussed last year, we built detailed restructuring plans across the company with the intent these would generate permanent expense reductions, allow the company to execute more efficiently with fewer moving parts and prepare for greater scalability in the future. 
In November, we announced headcount actions primarily targeting noncore areas in order to minimize impact on our ability to service customers and drive revenue. Generally speaking, I'd say we broke these notifications down into 2 events: the first one occurred in mid-November and the second one concluded in early January. I would point out that many of these roles have transitioned elements to them so that expense realization will be phased in throughout the year. 
In Q4, we posted 32% adjusted op margin. This is up nearly 600 basis points from last year. This is actually the highest margin of any quarter over the last 10 years. For the full year, we delivered 26% as compared to just 22% in 2014, well ahead of our original guidance the beginning of the year. And currently, I'd say, I think, we're well on our way to achieving the 30%-plus goal that we laid out for fiscal '17. This focus on leverage has also helped increase cash flow from operations, which was $282 million in Q4 and over $1 billion for the full year and this clearly a record for the company. When you translate this, it's about $6.45 a share for all of 2015. 
And finally, remained active with our buyback program last quarter. We repurchased 4.3 million shares and this increases the total for the full year to over 11 million shares. We also announced today that the board has authorized an additional $400 million to fund our ongoing program. So before I wrap up, let me talk about our current outlook and expectations for Q1 '16 and for the full year. Our operational programs are clearly working and say we're very happy with the results so far, and we're confident in our plans for the balance of the year. At the same time, we want to remain mindful of any potential disruptions that can occur really with any restructuring. So with that, we intend to remain conservative across many of our assumptions but we will be increasing our current expectations. For Q1 '16, we expect revenue in a range of $785 million to $790 million, and adjusted EPS between $0.91 and $0.93 a share. For fiscal '16, revenue between $3.31 billion and $3.32 billion, and adjusted EPS of $4.65 to $4.75 per share. And as a reminder, this guidance represents all businesses, including GoTo. So now I'd like to turn it over to Bob to give further color on the quarter. Bob?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. I'm very excited to have the opportunity to speak with you today for a host of reasons. First, I want to provide more context around the solid results that David just shared. Next, I want to give you an update on the progress we've been
componenttext:
Thank you, David. I'm very excited to have the opportunity to speak with you today for a host of reasons. First, I want to provide more context around the solid results that David just shared. Next, I want to give you an update on the progress we've been making to refocus our strategy and execute on the ongoing operating initiatives we outlined in November. And last but certainly not least, I want to share my excitement and introduce you to Citrix's new President and Chief Executive Officer. 
So let's get started. First, needless to say, I'm very pleased with the performance this quarter on both the top line and the bottom line. On the top line, the performance was impressive in and of itself, and even more so when you consider that we were implementing a number of restructuring activities in the sales organization during the fourth quarter. Carlos Sartorius and his team demonstrated is that it's possible to restructure the organization, and keep focus on execution, not only delivering on our expectations, but far exceeding with the beat of more than $25 million with most of that upside coming from product and license revenues. 
After a few consecutive quarters of declining license revenue, we posted solid gains on both Q3 and Q4. As David pointed out, we had good performance once again and our NetScaler's strategic service provider segment. However, it's also important to point out that performance continues to improve in Workspace Services as well where we saw a positive license revenue growth for the first time in a while, which is even more encouraging when you consider the mix shift towards more subscription and term-based licenses. I believe this is a function of improving execution and also, the early benefits of our renewed focus on secure apps and data delivery, which has received excellent feedback from our employees, partners and customers alike. This focus allows us to put all of our energy and resources into what is most important to us and to our customers, which I believe, is a key contributor to our top-line performance this quarter. 
A few weeks ago, I had the opportunity to participate in Citrix Summit, which is our annual kickoff with our sales team and our partners. You could feel the energy in the room as a collective team had just participated in an excellent end of the year. Both our sales team and partners had very positive feedback about the event, and they were particularly appreciative of the focus of the company, our simplified go-to-market strategy and our reenergized partner program. 
On the partner front, they were excited decided not only about the clarity we provided on the portfolio, but also about the innovation we are driving our core products. At the event, we showcased new capabilities for Microsoft technologies, browser-based apps and software-defined win. These innovations lineup for some of the major buying cycles going on in the tech sector that played Citrix trends. Citrix can significantly accelerate and simplify the migration to Windows 10. We'll be ready with similar capabilities to preserve our 2016 when it launches later this year, and our new optimization pack delivers deep integration within the Skype architecture, allowing us to deliver virtualized Skype functionality to Windows, Mac and Lenox desktops, making as a preferred partner for Skype for Business and giving us the lead competitive position. There are also host of other IT buying trends at Citrix is in great position to capitalize on. For example, the massive adoption of Chromebooks, an explosion in the use of browser-based apps is creating new opportunities for us to simplify and secure the delivery of apps for our customers. At Summit, we announced our browser app service that eliminates the headaches of browser version compatibility and mitigate security risks involved with browser-based apps. 
In addition to these market trends, we're also benefiting from our focus on industry verticals, especially in financial services and health care. By focusing on these verticals, we add features to our core products that meet to the needs of specific industry use cases, which gives us a significant competitive advantage. Along with our focus in execution, this is enabled us to be the competition and in several cases, resulted in competitive takeouts versus VMWare, which is reflected in our accidents results this quarter. The competitive wins are definitely turning in our favor, that is true with customers evidence by a number of competitive takeouts, it's true with -- and partners as well. That's on the recruiting front. 
I'm equally pleased with the progress on cost and margin improvement. When we last met, I shared how the recommendations from our strategic and operating reviews were not only focus the business on our core competencies and segments where we have or can built a defensive leadership position but also the streamlined organization to improve execution and reduced to the ongoing cost structure of the business. As you can see in the results this quarter, we are making great strides with adjusted operating margins up nearly 600 basis points year-on-year. A number of our initiatives are already implemented, and we are on track with more than 30 individual projects realizing faster savings, which is reflected in the quarter's results, as well as in the increased EPS guidance for 2016. 
Back in November, we set goals for 2016, which I characterized as conservative. The team did an outstanding job this quarter of performing, while implementing the restructuring. Yet, I believe it's prudent to remain conservative and realize a few more quarters of consistent performance before we raise expectations further. Considering current performance and the recent trends in the business, I would say our 2016 guidance remains very conservative, if not more so today. 
Before introducing Kirill, let me just say a few words of things to the team for the tremendous support they've given me over the past 6 months since I first joined at this exact chair and more recently, as Interim CEO. We have a terrific team here at Citrix. It's a very smart team, they're dedicated and the culture is ingrained with a deep desire to win and a competitive spirit that I'm very accustomed to. They have given me all the support I could ask for and they have shown what they can do when focused on the core mission and freed from distractions. They rapidly embraced the changes in the business and have shown that less can be more, not only more profit, but more revenue as well. And they've shown that they can drive results in the business, while simultaneously implementing difficult restructuring actions. The mission is not complete. Far from it, but I'm encouraged by the progress to date. The wins are clearly shifting in our favor, the team is energized and confident, they are competing more aggressively and winning in the market. The building momentum build the business as evidence not just by my words but by their performance. I'm very proud to been part of the cement think full for the support I received as Interim CEO. I look forward to continuing on as Exec Chair as we build upon our great start. Going forward, my focus first and foremost is on providing Kirill and the team any support they need. And beyond that, I plan to continue to stay involved in the restructuring and operating actions we outlined in November, the spin out of our GoTo business and in capital structure items. 
So finally, let me say how pleased I am to have Kirill join as our new Chief Executive Officer. I and the rest of the search committee conducted a very thorough search. We consider the number of candidates focus on those with the background that includes both leadership experience, as well as technology and products expertise. Most importantly, we look for leaders of shared our company's core values and the relentless focus on customer and partner's success. Kirill has a proven track record of growing businesses and driving operational performance. When you coupled that with his deep product background and the fact that he knows our space, our competitors and our biggest partners, there could not be a better fit between a candidate and an opportunity. So I'm really excited to have Kirill joined and lead this company to our next phase of growth. So with that, let me officially welcome Kirill to Citrix and turn the call over to him so he can introduce himself and say hello. Kirill?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and hello, everyone. I'm extremely excited to be part of Citrix. I've known Citrix over the years as a peer and a partner in the industry and I always viewed Citrix as a great company with highly respected brand, differentiated products, s
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and hello, everyone. I'm extremely excited to be part of Citrix. I've known Citrix over the years as a peer and a partner in the industry and I always viewed Citrix as a great company with highly respected brand, differentiated products, strong team, large and loyal partner channel and amazing customers around the world. In fact, many of whom I also served in my prior roles. 
Today is only my third day with the companies I wanted to share just a couple of thoughts on why I'm so excited about joining Citrix. With my discussions with many CIOs over the years, it is clear that secure delivery of apps and data is one of the most important priorities in driving digital transformations in their company and helping people in their organizations work better. And this is precisely what Citrix does. Personally, joining Citrix feels a bit like a homecoming for me. Throughout my career, I've been passing about helping people at work to be more productive. I've been fortunate to have an opportunity to build and lead innovative organizations with multi-product portfolios. And I had an opportunity to grow businesses at scale through partner-centric go-to-market model. So it seems like a perfect seat. I'm delighted Bob is staying on as our Executive Chairman, continuing the projects initiated last fall and helping me onboard and immersed in the business. I look forward to working with Bob and the leadership team to execute on Citrix's operating plan and drive greater value for our customers, partners and shareholders. I want to thank you for joining us today, and I look forward to engaging with many of you in the coming weeks and months. And now, I'd like to open up for questions.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's David. Let me just repeat a few things that I said earlier. And really, what's going on the Workspace Services is the culmination of a lot of these activities we've talked about over the last several quarters, not only to reinstate the focus on
componenttext:
Sure, it's David. Let me just repeat a few things that I said earlier. And really, what's going on the Workspace Services is the culmination of a lot of these activities we've talked about over the last several quarters, not only to reinstate the focus on that app, but all of the other technologies that are around that to create those types of solutions. In terms of the actual drivers, 2 big things I'd call out. First is the holistic Workspace Suite. Everyone knows that's our solution for enterprise mobility, talk about apps and mobility and data in 1 broader, more strategic conversation with customers. That is up to about 20% of the mix right now. That was less than 10% a year ago, growing at close to 200% year-on-year. 
Second piece is actually around our service provider business, is the CSPs. That is all subscription-based, monthly ratable, approaching a $60 million business and growing north of 30%. That's really the big one. We're also the driving lots of innovation forward. So things that Bob called out, whether it's the focus on helping customers win 10 migrations, virtualizing Skype for business, browser servers, new management capabilities, lots of things in that area, really just demonstrated in exhilarating the market leadership we've had for all these years. That's the message we're carrying for the at the partners, that's the message our sales teams are driving and is allowing for the continuous improvement in overall execution. I'd say back to the comment about the geos, yes, in Q4, the Americas was really the big driver. I made a comment in my prepared remarks about that's the place where we initiated our restructuring last year. So they got a lot more time to work through all of the changes, get settled into them new structure in a good report as a setter was, so we are as we roll into '16 you'll see a similar type of performance flow-through in the other geos.

Those are really the biggest headwinds they are and the easiest way to normalize the '15 to '16 guide.

componenttext: Steve, I'd say at a high level of the way to think about it is, we've just simplified the approach for how we were engaged in the partners pick with simplified everything from the types of accounts where they are eligible to participate. There had been some segmentation in the past, we've removed of that. The idea is just how do we engage with the channel instead of driving us versus yours. I think, those that's probably the easiest way to describe the changes between '15 and '16. The other is around the simplification and focus message that we talked about over the past couple of quarters. Certainly, our partners want to hear that as well. Here's what we're focused on, here's what's most important then, here's how they make money for their businesses, and then just drive in the relentless focus against that. And so that's why we're seeing better and better results. One stat I would just call out this it's fairly early on but in Q4, we had about a 15% increase in actual CSA partners that we are selling products so that's our real during the trip partners and share with the vibrating our channel. Very important going forward.

componenttext: Sure. There's a big focus that we placed on broader mid-market when we're with partners just a couple of weeks ago. And it's not necessarily just a general conversation, but it's much more holistic about within that, and it needs to start with understanding the needs of the customers, making sure we've got the right products and services to address that, and then the go-to-market motion that makes sense. We're kind of attacking that top to bottom. Some of the products that we have talked about today whether they're browser, servers and things that are just easier to adopt and manage and scale, more targeted towards the mid-market. So internally, we talked a lot about land and expand, and you'll hear more about that certainly as we get into the second quarter and synergy with partners and customers in the May timeframe.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Delivery Networking is the overall business is doing well. I talked about the 3 main pieces in my prepared remarks and I think, that's the way you should expect us to discuss networking going forward. The attached motion is the first piece and that is whe
componenttext:
Delivery Networking is the overall business is doing well. I talked about the 3 main pieces in my prepared remarks and I think, that's the way you should expect us to discuss networking going forward. The attached motion is the first piece and that is where customers are purchasing really Workspace Services solution and and networking product in conjunction to create more of a system. Not only does it provide more value for Citrix on a bookings double, but it creates a lot of differentiation to our value for our customers, that's one. The stuff that I called out is that we had 800 of those types of transactions in the quarter versus 700 a year ago. If you invert the metric, that's about a 12% attach rate to virtualization orders, and that's up from 9% a year ago. So that's one of the key focus areas. 
The second is around what we would describe as core ADC. And this is enterprise ADC that's largely a focus area for coverage, and so one of the investments that we're making right now is to increase coverage in multiple geos that should allow us to be able to service many more of those engagements. And then the third is around strategic service providers, which as everyone knows, we have tremendous engagement with a handful of large customers but their purchasing patterns tend to be a bit volatile. So overall we expect to be able to grow in-line or faster than the market in '16, but be a little bit cautious about the timing of the SSPs piece and where are those yet.

componenttext: Kirill, welcome to Citrix. If we could just hear from you in terms of your commitment to the plan laid out by the previous management team and what's your vision for the company, how do you think it would look into 2 to 3 years from now?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would answer it in one word, the commitment is unwavering. But obviously, opportunity to study the plan and depth. I think it's an amazing plan and I think the team has done amazing job last quarter executing on this plan. And my job 1 is to stay
componenttext: Well, I would answer it in one word, the commitment is unwavering. But obviously, opportunity to study the plan and depth. I think it's an amazing plan and I think the team has done amazing job last quarter executing on this plan. And my job 1 is to stay the course, continue to plan, continue executing on the plan and drive it forward.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I mentioned, in my remarks earlier, secure delivery of apps and data is at a very private prior CIOs around the world. Mobility plays an important part of that and I'm really encouraged with the solutions that we have in the future that it would bring
componenttext: As I mentioned, in my remarks earlier, secure delivery of apps and data is at a very private prior CIOs around the world. Mobility plays an important part of that and I'm really encouraged with the solutions that we have in the future that it would bring to those customers. Taking beyond that, I'd probably take a couple more days before I start talking to about the future vision 2 years out and I hope you would give me those couple of days.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second part of the question. This is Bob on VMWare. I'd say the company had a very good quarter relative to the competition this quarter. Looking at a long list of competitive wins, some of those were head-to-head wins for new business and frankly, th
componenttext: The second part of the question. This is Bob on VMWare. I'd say the company had a very good quarter relative to the competition this quarter. Looking at a long list of competitive wins, some of those were head-to-head wins for new business and frankly, there are a number of pity significant competitive takeouts this quarter versus VMware. So I'd say, as I mentioned in my comments, the competitive wins are definitely moving in our favor. That was building as the quarter went on. And I would say that's true from our customer point of view given the wins. I would say that's true from our partner point of view, I think, the partners has definitely noticed some very good changes in the relationship with Citrix here from just the way we're partnering better in the field. They like to focus and the renewed energy around the quarter of our business and I would say on the recruiting front as well. So even with employees, I think, we've definitely seen a shift in activity there as well. So we're feeling -- I would say we're feeling rather bullish right now and very optimistic going into 2016.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gregg Moskowitz from Cowan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gregg Moskowitz from Cowan.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, as you noted earlier, Workspace Services showed positive license growth in for the first time in a while. Clearly, this was not something that would expected by The Street. I realize it's early in the game with respect to the refinery strategy to foc
componenttext: Bob, as you noted earlier, Workspace Services showed positive license growth in for the first time in a while. Clearly, this was not something that would expected by The Street. I realize it's early in the game with respect to the refinery strategy to focus on secure apps and David delivery, but do you think that positive license growth in the segment is sustainable?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, when we adjusted the plan here, it was all about focus. And we said we're going to focus on secure apps and data delivery and that was going to allow us to streamline the organization and reduce cost. And I think, there was probably too much e
componenttext: Well, look, when we adjusted the plan here, it was all about focus. And we said we're going to focus on secure apps and data delivery and that was going to allow us to streamline the organization and reduce cost. And I think, there was probably too much emphasis or maybe too many people attached that to a cost-reduction focus. Yes, we are reducing cost and we are improving margins, but I fundamentally believe that a more focused organization is a better executing organization. We have all the wood behind the fewer arrows in this organization. So every single person, whether you're in sales, whether you're in services, whether you're in engineering, whether you're in customer support, every single person in this organization is going to execute better with that focus. And I believe it's early still, but I believe the results and the improved results and the growth that we saw this quarter is the early signs of the benefits we're going to see from that focus and I expect as we roll out 2016 we'll continue to see the benefits of that focus. We're not going to forecast revenue than an out of I do expect continued improvement and continued execution as we benefit from my renewed focus.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up for David. So you're R&D expense, I believe, went down in Q4 by about $6 million and is now below 14% of revenues. How are you thinking about R&D this year versus 2015?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up for David. So you're R&D expense, I believe, went down in Q4 by about $6 million and is now below 14% of revenues. How are you thinking about R&D this year versus 2015?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say overall just you take a step back, and you look at the OpEx as a percent of revenue. I mean, in 2014, we're running right around 63%, '15 we are running 60% and this year, our guidance was puts you probably at 56%, 57% of revenue. And that's,
componenttext: Yes, I'd say overall just you take a step back, and you look at the OpEx as a percent of revenue. I mean, in 2014, we're running right around 63%, '15 we are running 60% and this year, our guidance was puts you probably at 56%, 57% of revenue. And that's, that's good from a margin point of view. That's driving the direction we're trying to get to. But when you take a step back and if you recall what we talked about in November, a lot of our focus efforts were around actually increasing the investment in our core solutions and we're doing that by trimming away things, we're contributing to revenue where we done that, et cetera, et cetera. And so if you look at very specific took our products like then and for example, there's not a single engineer has been removed from that organization. In fact, we'll be increasing investment there and networking and data, et cetera. And so don't focus too much on the absolute, I think, it would be more important to focus on the individual initiatives that we're driving. Long-term, 14%, 15%, 16% of revenue is relatively typical for large software companies some economies of scale and a few pretty comfortable about the capacity we have overall in the system.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttextpreview: And just 2 quick questions. One, David, I was wondering -- I know it's early but in November, you gave us some early color on calendar '17. I'm just wondering if you could give us a sense of given Q4 results, if you can update that -- update us on whether
componenttext: And just 2 quick questions. One, David, I was wondering -- I know it's early but in November, you gave us some early color on calendar '17. I'm just wondering if you could give us a sense of given Q4 results, if you can update that -- update us on whether or not that still stands? And then I guess, just another question and an apologist if this was asked by was another call. You at a competitor last night talking about market share gains. I'm just wondering if you could give a little bit of color on kind of what you're seeing in the end-user computing market and how you see the competitive environments evolving?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take the first part of that question and I'll have Bob address the second part. 2017, yes, unchanged in terms of the way we're thinking about it. Honestly Heather just getting into '16 right now, so that's a primary focus. But when we are in N
componenttext: Yes, let me take the first part of that question and I'll have Bob address the second part. 2017, yes, unchanged in terms of the way we're thinking about it. Honestly Heather just getting into '16 right now, so that's a primary focus. But when we are in November we laid out a growth rate of 4%, 5% of our from the top line for '17 and north of 30% operating margin for the full year. And I feel very good about those at this point in time. I mean, one of the things that we had covered was just the impact of of some these discontinued businesses that the primary reason why revenues dipping into '16 and once we normalized that we have a much better -- much clearer picture of the corporate business. So once that normalized, year-over-year comps look good. The accelerated investments that we're making into things will facilitate drive long-term growth, I think, are still in place as we layer in increased capacity in areas, go-to-market areas like networking et cetera. I think, that all for good things for '17. So no change, feel good about the progress so far and clearly, we're executing well it shows up in Q4. Bob, you want to talk about the competitive environment?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, David. Heather, I think earlier, I made some comments about the competitive wins turning in our favor. We certainly see that on the win-loss data. We see that competitive takeouts. I think, they'd seen it in our results where our Workspace se
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, David. Heather, I think earlier, I made some comments about the competitive wins turning in our favor. We certainly see that on the win-loss data. We see that competitive takeouts. I think, they'd seen it in our results where our Workspace service business continues to improve. So what I see, our competitive wins, I see our results improving, I see our backlog increasing. That's what I see. It's a little bit different than what I hear. I know you referred to that in your question on some comments made yesterday, what I hear is a little bit different than what I see. What I hear is $1 billion business growing at 30%. I hear collection of $1 billion businesses growing at 20% or 30%, but when you look at total results, you see 1 present decline in license revenue that quarter. So I guess, I need somebody a little bit better than number to explain how that works, but the things I see look really good and the things I hear, I frankly don't believe.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Weiss from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is for wanted for Keith Weiss. I wanted to see if you could give us some insights into the product roadmap over 2016 and 2017 with a renewed focus on the core data delivery side of the product portfolio. What can your channel partners and your custom
componenttext: This is for wanted for Keith Weiss. I wanted to see if you could give us some insights into the product roadmap over 2016 and 2017 with a renewed focus on the core data delivery side of the product portfolio. What can your channel partners and your customers expect from a product roadmap standpoint? And then as a quick follow-up, and terms of their geographic commentary, we didn't call any sort of macro weakness or any spending environment and we've heard some commentary to that end from a couple of software companies, so we wanted to see if your take on the spending environment, particularly, in a packed it's also you're talking about more restructuring going on there than anything really to spending environment in APAC. I just wanted to get your thoughts on that point as well?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, let me touch on those 2 separately. In terms of long-term product roadmaps I mean, it's probably not an appropriate time to do it on a call like this. Shorter term, yes, we've talked to partners about just a pretty rapid ramp in innovation across la
componenttext: Sure, let me touch on those 2 separately. In terms of long-term product roadmaps I mean, it's probably not an appropriate time to do it on a call like this. Shorter term, yes, we've talked to partners about just a pretty rapid ramp in innovation across late 2015, '16 in the Workspace Services areas. For those of you that have followed the company for a while, remember that we went through a major platform transition for a couple of years around XenApps and Desktop, et cetera. With that guidance we been able to really ramp the new innovation, new features, things like that, just focusing on what customers need, how to be more successful, how to bridge between on-prem, hybrid and full cloud deployments et cetera. So that's the thematically it's what we're doing in that area. You see a lot of new improvements coming out in terms of just ways we integrate from a management layer, from end-user experience, performance across lousy networks, the types of things that really matter to customers. We've laid all that out, and we'll be talking a lot more about that at synergy in the May timeframe. Networking, very similar. We've taken our software-based strategy and really extended that across the platforms over the last couple of years. For example, I didn't talk about this in the prepared remarks, but our virtual appliances, the VPX family, is actually the fastest growing elements of networking. That grew well over 20% for the full year and in the quarter as customers are utilizing a virtual appliance more in the think about in the context of from a data fabric versus a physical box in the data center. And so lots of things like that are going to the theater drive forward there aggressively. And then, of course, close illusions, which are a little bit further out in the future. So core messages, come to synergy, we'd love to have everybody see the latest and Grace will talk much more about future roadmaps they are. In terms of the market environment, I think, a number of companies have talked about macro and currency, and that's all true. Outside of the U.S., markets are a little bit more volatile than they are domestically. I think, everybody's just operating under the same base assumptions, and we saw some of that as well. We didn't really feel worth calling out because frankly, that's the way it's been the past 2, 3 quarters anyway. Fairly challenging in parts of APAC. Certainly, challenging in places in South America and others where you've just had lots of currency volatility. And frankly, the same -- it holds true for me especially those markets that are more focused on energy. we're executing through that. We're really focus on the things that we can control, and that's what we're talking about now. Happy with what's going on in the Americas, we've got a great new leadership in the EMEA space, and we're excited about the things that we can accomplish in '16. So stay with us. We'll give you an update in each and every quarter.

componenttext: Question on XenApp. You mentioned earlier in your comments that there were new engineering costs to XenApp and we've heard about this product to being a focus for management over several quarters. But can you offer some color around how the performance has been -- do you see stabilizing, anything would be helpful on that front?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I mean if that question is like XenApp versus XenDesktop, versus Suite versus others, those are packaging discussions more than anything else. The way to think about the business is in the aggregate. We have certainly seen more individual transacti
componenttext: Scott, I mean if that question is like XenApp versus XenDesktop, versus Suite versus others, those are packaging discussions more than anything else. The way to think about the business is in the aggregate. We have certainly seen more individual transactions moved from point products like XenApp or XenDesktop to Workspace Suite. And that's a good thing. That's a focus of our message right now as we're talking to customers about level that encompasses all types of apps call types of data, et cetera. That's why the Suite's growing as fast as it is. The individual products move up and down depending on customer requirements for each individual transaction.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First on the operating margin. You mentioned, David, this is the best margin and I think, you said 10 years since you're up 400 basis point, but yet it seems that the full sort of, I think, you said some of the restructuring will st
componenttext: A couple of questions. First on the operating margin. You mentioned, David, this is the best margin and I think, you said 10 years since you're up 400 basis point, but yet it seems that the full sort of, I think, you said some of the restructuring will still be in effect in January. It seems like maybe -- can you just tell us about your margin guidance and how conservative it is, and then, of course, be impact of GoTo, I think, you said and there as well?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Catherine. Let me set the stage a little bit. When you look at the 2 big businesses, GoTo and the enterprise business. The enterprise business is currently operating at a bit of a higher margin than the GoTo. Just fairly common for SaaS-based busine
componenttext: Sure, Catherine. Let me set the stage a little bit. When you look at the 2 big businesses, GoTo and the enterprise business. The enterprise business is currently operating at a bit of a higher margin than the GoTo. Just fairly common for SaaS-based businesses. So when I talk about margin guidance, however, that is the whole call for everything. We'll go back and update guidance as upper period once the spin is complete sometime in the second half of the year. So from a whole quarter point of view, we went from 22.5% in '14 to little over 25.% in '15 and our guidance for '16 is north of 28%. Think when you run the numbers our current financial guidance, you'll land somewhere around 28.5% and so we're quite comfortable with that. In terms of, whether it's conservative or not, hopefully with hindsight, everything is conservative but that's our guidance that still stands today.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a quick question for you, Kirill. Traditionally, Microsoft and Citrix has had historically tight relationship and you're coming from Microsoft now. Can you talk about maybe any areas that you see a high level where the companies can continue to w
componenttext: And then a quick question for you, Kirill. Traditionally, Microsoft and Citrix has had historically tight relationship and you're coming from Microsoft now. Can you talk about maybe any areas that you see a high level where the companies can continue to work together particularly as respect to cloud?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, I think we refer to say of the company together over the years very well. And just studying what's transpired earlier this month at the summit. Microsoft participated at the Summit and was very excited about innovation that brings to market
componenttext: Well, I think, I think we refer to say of the company together over the years very well. And just studying what's transpired earlier this month at the summit. Microsoft participated at the Summit and was very excited about innovation that brings to market, in particular, supporting Skype business and several other initiatives. And I can only expect this will continue and accelerate going forward. Look forward to being partners.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John DiFucci from Jefferies.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I have first the question, then a question for Kirill. This is, I think the second quarter in a row may be more than that for really strong service provider contribution to NetScaler. And this is historically sort have been a periodic or cyclical s
componenttext: David, I have first the question, then a question for Kirill. This is, I think the second quarter in a row may be more than that for really strong service provider contribution to NetScaler. And this is historically sort have been a periodic or cyclical sort of cadence with the major service providers. But has it turned into more than that? Is this more -- could this be the start of a more of a secular trend service providers were to accommodate sort of cloud build -- build-outs. And I guess, I know, it's hard to tell, but you have a pipeline you can see to and I'm just wondering when you look at the last couple of quarters anyway, and then you look out in the future, with that look like?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. Yes, a service provider is our really important segment of the business. For those of you that have followed NetScaler for a long time, remember that it was nearly 100% of total revenue if you roll the clock back 7 or 8 years. We've diversifie
componenttext: Sure, John. Yes, a service provider is our really important segment of the business. For those of you that have followed NetScaler for a long time, remember that it was nearly 100% of total revenue if you roll the clock back 7 or 8 years. We've diversified broadly across the idea of the way I describe it is attached, but settings solutions and then core enterprise ADC. It remains one of our most important, but like you said, it's a little volatile. I mean what's happened over the years is that it's more from being a big spike in Q3 as dotcoms were focused on what was frankly the holiday shopping season, building out capacity for that. Too much more distributed now where people are delivering services to mobile devices, services to just SaaS and those type of things. So the businesses much more broad than it used to be. I'd say we have pretty good visibility into the full year. It's just that the timing of purchases tend to be concentrated based on when customers need it. And so one of the hesitations we have about giving quarter-to-quarter guidance at that level is that it does move around. If you remember back in 2014, we had a tremendous first half of the year with the SSP segment, and then a little bit weaker in the back half of the year. Going on to '15, we said it was going to be the opposite. So that came true and first half was lighter with the SSPs and that the second half was very strong. When we look at it in hindsight, the full year, pretty much as expected. And so that is the only pause that I have when talking about guidance for that segment is that it's predicated on their build cycles. Full year, I think we've got good relationships, really happy with our share and we're going to work very closely with them on all of their needs.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. So we're not quite sure with it but this might continue to be somewhat volatile? And I guess, I have a follow-up. First of all, congratulations to Kirill, is congrats that's great. And then. I realize you have operational experience with Micr
componenttext: Okay, great. So we're not quite sure with it but this might continue to be somewhat volatile? And I guess, I have a follow-up. First of all, congratulations to Kirill, is congrats that's great. And then. I realize you have operational experience with Microsoft and DMC, but I also know your roots are truly as a technologist. And listen, I know you had a couple of questions there on this but any want to give you the chance to sort of assists what Citrix has. But for what I know of you, I'm sure you did your due diligence and at least -- least initially, I think, you said listen, we have a plan and ongoing to execute on the plan and that's great but as far as the context of the plan, the Citrix is a technology company and there's problem, I'm sure you have like have taken a look at. Just curious, even from a high level from your perspective, what areas do you think there are opportunities to further advance Citrix's position in technology in a more meaningful way? I mean, even from a high level, if you could just give your thoughts. I'm sure you have some.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, if you step back and look at the start of major drivers both the industry today major drivers both the digital transformation, you clearly see mobility and you clearly see related to mobility, secure delivery of apps and data. That's what every CIO
componenttext: Look, if you step back and look at the start of major drivers both the industry today major drivers both the digital transformation, you clearly see mobility and you clearly see related to mobility, secure delivery of apps and data. That's what every CIO wants to see the organization, and that's with Citrix drive and I think, the product portfolios supported in a very significant away, and I'm really excited about that particular part of the business, Workspace Services and how it can continue to play that role. Obviously, clouds is another hugely significant trend and NetScaler business that have NetScaler essentially becoming such a huge enabler of the worldwide essentially serving such a huge portion of our cloud transactions for the major service providers is just astounding and I fully expect this to continue and accelerates as the world continues to shift to the cloud, which is now unstoppable as people build out more data centers, serving servers and clouds and more clouds around the world. And then, of course, data and sharing data and enabling sort of analytics empowered by big data and the role that ShareFile technology place in that particular trend as it relates to highly regulated industries. That's another very important powerful trend that I see only accelerating in the future. And so those 3 things combined from the technology point of view it as I went for my due diligence on the Citrix technical but folio, that what gets me really excited about that opportunity and I think, that's what propels this company into the future to the next phase of greatness.

componenttext: We haven't broken out individual products for a while but I'd say that when I look at and mobile is a standalone, I mean, more and more of the individual opportunities are more towards Suite. So it's it's it's one of the big, big drivers for white customers would move from, let's say, XenApp to the full suite. And so that's where the conversation started, and that's the primary driver for why it's up in terms of overall mix. From a market point of view, I mean similar trends to what we're seeing in the past, I mean, people are more conservative higher up the stack talking about the amount and anything in the device level. So no change on that front. I don't think we'll plan on breaking it out with a lot of granularity going forward, because there's just there's packaging options. And I think, will skew the numbers a bit, but we'll provide more directional guidance as we get into '16.

componenttextpreview: It's been for Matt Tandberg. You've talked about the changes made in the U.S. being done before the rest of the world a couple of times on the call now just curious about the timing that the U.S. has had, is that 1 quarter, is it 4 quarters, and then are
componenttext: It's been for Matt Tandberg. You've talked about the changes made in the U.S. being done before the rest of the world a couple of times on the call now just curious about the timing that the U.S. has had, is that 1 quarter, is it 4 quarters, and then are you using essentially the same playbook overseas?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say that the U.S. initiated a lot of restructuring earlier in '15 and whether that was just moving from our distributed model to one that focuses on the product segments, some changes in the channel engagement model. So when we started in that sa
componenttext: Yes, I'd say that the U.S. initiated a lot of restructuring earlier in '15 and whether that was just moving from our distributed model to one that focuses on the product segments, some changes in the channel engagement model. So when we started in that say the first half of last year, I don't want to imply that the other deals haven't been going to restructuring because they have it's just that there are couple of 3 quarters behind just in terms of maturity of the model. We've also gone through leadership evolution in EMEA, and so that is all completed and in the Q4 time frame. So are expecting good, solid constant performance out of that deal in 2016.

And -- I'd say in the product front, we're largely through it at least at an initiation level, I mean, everything's got execution the trails a few quarters and I made a high level comments about some of the people-related actions that we've got all behind us right now. But there's if you recall the approach we took was not tops-down cost-cutting approach but really a bottoms-up focused on the business focused on long-term, focused on the things that matter, and so because of that there's a number of transitions in place right now and many of those frankly, are in the product area. Hard decisions have been made that's behind us and now it's just about execution. So I'd say we're well on our way.
