componenttext: Kirill, welcome onboard. First question for you Kirill, can you talk a little bit about the -- you came from Microsoft. Microsoft has their own mobile solution. How do you envision that relationship with Microsoft to evolve for Citrix going forward with you on board now?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you very much, and thanks for the welcome. Obviously, Citrix and Microsoft have a long-standing history of partnership and terrific relationship, and that partnership certainly continues and expands to many areas. I think the work that we've do
componenttext: Yes, thank you very much, and thanks for the welcome. Obviously, Citrix and Microsoft have a long-standing history of partnership and terrific relationship, and that partnership certainly continues and expands to many areas. I think the work that we've done together on Skype for Business is one example of that terrific partnership. The work that we're doing with Microsoft on Windows 10 and helping Microsoft customers roll out Windows 10 quickly is another example of that partnership. And we're looking for many other ways to collaborate, and we continue to work very closely together in many other areas, including enterprise mobility.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And David, one question. Like you obviously had a very, very strong start to the year on the operating margins. How much of that was just coming -- stuff coming through quicker than expected versus actually you are identifying new areas?
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And David, one question. Like you obviously had a very, very strong start to the year on the operating margins. How much of that was just coming -- stuff coming through quicker than expected versus actually you are identifying new areas?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Raimo, if you're asking in terms of from the expense point of view, obviously, margin's a function of [indiscernible] plus expense. But our restructuring is a little bit ahead of plan. I mean, we've been executing across the company very effectively. I th
componenttext: Raimo, if you're asking in terms of from the expense point of view, obviously, margin's a function of [indiscernible] plus expense. But our restructuring is a little bit ahead of plan. I mean, we've been executing across the company very effectively. I think we're -- we have taken a bottoms-up approach as we discussed over the last couple of quarters, and this just allows the teams to really, really  own the business and own the restructuring items. So I think we're just doing a great job across the company. So obviously, we're taking up our full year margin expectation by about 100 basis points already here in Q1, so feeling really good about that as well.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Kash Rangan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Kash Rangan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when I look at the way in which you beat the operating income, more than 2/3 of that came from gross profit beats. So it doesn't look like it's purely an expense reduction story. So can you talk to the drivers of upside performance on the Xen side? And
componenttext: So when I look at the way in which you beat the operating income, more than 2/3 of that came from gross profit beats. So it doesn't look like it's purely an expense reduction story. So can you talk to the drivers of upside performance on the Xen side? And I think clearly, for years, we've been hearing Xen license flat to down. So this time, it's flat, which is obviously a nice positive reversal. And also, I don't believe that we've seen a strong double-digit growth on the networking side. Can you just talk to industry fundamentals versus how much of this is fundamentals in your end industry versus your execution? And color on why Asia Pacific was down so much as well, notwithstanding. Otherwise, a great result.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kash. A few questions in there, so let me parse that out a bit. Overall, talking about the industry and the demand environment, I'd say that the big stories in the quarter were the Americas' performance. Really did a great job, drove a lot of the
componenttext: Thanks, Kash. A few questions in there, so let me parse that out a bit. Overall, talking about the industry and the demand environment, I'd say that the big stories in the quarter were the Americas' performance. Really did a great job, drove a lot of the revenue, drove a lot of revenue upside as well. So those teams have been working through the restructuring from really the beginning of '15. So they're just humming along. We're a little bit further behind when it comes to the other 2 regions in terms of the work that we've been operating against. From a product standpoint, yes. NetScaler had a terrific quarter again, similar to the last -- really, the last 9 months have been very strong. It's a combination of strength across the big trends around cloud build-out, cloud services, et cetera. We're also continuing to expand the customer opportunity size. I called out more than 20% growth in customers within that segment. Interestingly enough, we're also seeing a pretty rapid growth of NetScaler being consumed as a cloud service. And so while still only a kind of mid-single digits of the mix, that business is growing well over 100% as well. Shifting gears and talking about Workspace Services, couple of things to point out. Clearly, we've been making good progress over the last several quarters. Some of the staffs that we referenced in the prepared remarks, the suite being the complete solution for talking with customers about app and data delivery, that was up about 100%. The overall CSP business, which, remind you, is full subscription, was up about 30%. And one data point that I didn't put in the prepared remarks but is also interesting is that when I look at units, units are actually growing year-on-year in the mid-single-digit range. And that's just a function of the mix of license type. So overall, for the Workspace Services business, about 18% of license this quarter was coming in via subscription. That compares to 14% a year go. So we've got a couple of different dynamics in play, but the overall message is that we're up into the right across all of our major product areas. We're seeing terrific execution out of the Americas. We were happy and above kind of our internal expectation in multiple product areas, and we still see further upside because there's more work to do.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, perhaps just a couple things on the secular trends that we're seeing that are clearly playing the role in driving results for the business. On the networking side, we all see the tremendous buildout of the data centers that continues, and NetScaler o
componenttext: Yes, perhaps just a couple things on the secular trends that we're seeing that are clearly playing the role in driving results for the business. On the networking side, we all see the tremendous buildout of the data centers that continues, and NetScaler offering unique capabilities in a software-defined fashion truly participates in that buildout and that's what we see in the growth in the cloud provider segment. At the same time, the growth in e-commerce and the fact that even those companies that historically weren't participating in that delivery of online goods and services are now right in there and they need to increase their networking throughput and capacity. That plays significant control. And of course, many have used NetScaler as essentially security product or part of their cybersecurity strategy, and that's not a trend that plays to that. On the app virtualization and on the sort of overall Workspace's services, XenApp is -- we're seeing significant interest in XenApp, and we see a significant interest in large customers wanting to virtualize applications. And we see actually good growth in that particular product. From the trends point of view, I would say the introduction of Windows 10 in the enterprise is starting to be a driver that we're seeing. And many large customers that I had a chance to have dialogue within the last -- in the last few weeks certainly looking at XenApp and XenDesktop as the sort of very significant important infrastructure for them to roll out Windows 10 in the enterprise. And we obviously expected that to grow and accelerate and continue. And the new product introductions that happen in Q1 will only help with that also through the Skype for Business and secure web browser.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard from Citi.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following on, on the last question. This XenApp for surgeons, I think many of us are trying to understand. You saw good business there last quarter and you've had like the 7.6 release, which I think may have released some pent-up demand. Kirill, can
componenttext: Just following on, on the last question. This XenApp for surgeons, I think many of us are trying to understand. You saw good business there last quarter and you've had like the 7.6 release, which I think may have released some pent-up demand. Kirill, can you help us understand just how sustainable you think growth, I guess, in XenApp license is? And maybe as part of that, could you highlight some of the use cases or value propositions beyond the sort of generic app virtualization that are driving demand there, because that product has gone through sort of phases of growth and maturity, and it's surprising to see how well it's doing.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's worth remembering that about 2 or 3 years, the company went through very significant engineering effort to lay out VDI and XenDesktop and XenApp on the same infrastructure. And that -- as we've seen in some examples, and Johns Hopkins i
componenttext: Well, I think it's worth remembering that about 2 or 3 years, the company went through very significant engineering effort to lay out VDI and XenDesktop and XenApp on the same infrastructure. And that -- as we've seen in some examples, and Johns Hopkins in particular, that we mentioned, we see customers want to run both virtualized desktop and virtualized app off the same infrastructure, and that's becoming more and more prominent and we see more and more of that. We also see customers who want to essentially create one single storefront for all their employees to access their workspaces, whether it's virtualized desktop access, virtualized app or files. They basically want to create the enterprise portal, enterprise store for them to use. And that's precisely where sort of unification plays an important role and where all of that working on the same infrastructure is quite significant. These are just a couple of things that we're seeing, and that going through many customer discussions, to me, sort of create both excitement on what happened in the last couple of quarters, but at the same time, confidence that we see some bright future for XenApp in particular.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then David, on the cost side, the one area that stuck out to us was with the R&D spend, which was down I think as we calculate, somewhere in the mid-teens year-over-year. That strikes me as maybe down more than -- either more than it should be or more
componenttext: And then David, on the cost side, the one area that stuck out to us was with the R&D spend, which was down I think as we calculate, somewhere in the mid-teens year-over-year. That strikes me as maybe down more than -- either more than it should be or more than it can be for some sustained period of time. Could you help us understand what's driving that? And how we should think about your level of R&D spend going forward?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't focus too much on the individual line items quarter-to-quarter. Let's get a couple more quarters into the year. There's really 2 things. First, the reason I say that is that there is always individual projects going on that may or may not
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't focus too much on the individual line items quarter-to-quarter. Let's get a couple more quarters into the year. There's really 2 things. First, the reason I say that is that there is always individual projects going on that may or may not have large consulting expense, there is events, other things that flow through there. The second one is a large part of our focus in streamlining was around the portfolio. And so as we have removed or sold or shut down products initiatives, that comes with the expense that was everything from engineering through support, through sales, et cetera. So that's really what you're seeing there. Overall, we've talked about freeing up capital so that we can reinvest in the areas that are strategic and that are going to drive growth long term, and that's been a core part of the strategy and we're executing on that. So overall, R&D somewhere running in that 12% to 16% of revenue is pretty typical, and I think that's where we're going to be as well.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, David, I had a question -- 2 questions. The cloud providers, I believe you said they were 60% of sales in the period. And obviously, the NetScaler business looked really good. I'm just wondering -- that does seem higher than normal. I thought in
componenttext: I guess, David, I had a question -- 2 questions. The cloud providers, I believe you said they were 60% of sales in the period. And obviously, the NetScaler business looked really good. I'm just wondering -- that does seem higher than normal. I thought in the past you've talked about it being more like 25% to 30%. And I'm just wondering, are these guys kind of buying in bigger bursts less frequently than they had in the past? Are you seeing any change, I guess, in their buying behavior? And then the other would be -- the question on top of that would be how do we think about the dip-down sequentially off of what's a huge number in Q1? And then I just had a follow-up on long-term deferreds.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the middle part of your question about the sequential change from Q1 to Q2, it's just a function of, as you said, the really strong outperformance in Q1. We want to be conservative going into Q2. Nothing more than that. In terms of the cloud serv
componenttext: Sure. On the middle part of your question about the sequential change from Q1 to Q2, it's just a function of, as you said, the really strong outperformance in Q1. We want to be conservative going into Q2. Nothing more than that. In terms of the cloud service providers, representing about 60% of the mix in Q1. It's all of the above from your earlier question. They're continuing to build out just core infrastructure as the meta-trend of cloud continues. There are new services being delivered all the time that require incremental capacity. And as I mentioned a little earlier, we've been expanding that base. So trying to keep the size of the opportunity expanding at the same time. So we added a couple of hundred customers to that segment, and it's really a combination of all 3 of those that are driving the growth. Over the past few quarters, Q4, for example, have represented about 45% of the mix. It was 60% in Q1. And so it does have the potential to be a little volatile and it's one of the reasons why we're being conservative for Q2, but nothing beyond that.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then -- sorry, go ahead.
componenttext: Okay. And then -- sorry, go ahead.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just going to add that the base is expanding and there are more customers that's being added to that pool.
componenttext: I was just going to add that the base is expanding and there are more customers that's being added to that pool.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And then the question on long-term deferreds was really the -- it looks like your contract duration, people are willing to pay you more upfront. Your long-term deferred trends over the last 3 quarters has been way stronger than what kind of seasona
componenttext: Right. And then the question on long-term deferreds was really the -- it looks like your contract duration, people are willing to pay you more upfront. Your long-term deferred trends over the last 3 quarters has been way stronger than what kind of seasonality would suggest in the past. Can you just talk a little bit about what's driving that?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, customers are driving that actually. I mean, we're not incenting the teams to drive multiyear arrangements more so than customers are simply asking for that. And it's just a function of becoming more and more strategic in their infrastructure. I can
componenttext: Yes, customers are driving that actually. I mean, we're not incenting the teams to drive multiyear arrangements more so than customers are simply asking for that. And it's just a function of becoming more and more strategic in their infrastructure. I can think of the largest transaction in the quarter, which was with a U.S. federal entity that included the 4 years of underlying maintenance. And that was part of the overall contract that mapped to the outsourcing that they were doing with an additional provider. And so it's instances like that, that's really driving the long-term deferred. But overall, it's just a function of -- it's critical part of their infrastructure, and we are becoming more strategic. And I think that trend, as it's continued over the last couple of years, should continue going forward.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John DiFucci from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John DiFucci from Jefferies.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. The first one that's being asked quite a bit here, and David, I think I asked you -- might have asked you this question last quarter. I mean, the -- I think when you first got into this, the business with NetScaler, there was some criticism
componenttext: Two questions. The first one that's being asked quite a bit here, and David, I think I asked you -- might have asked you this question last quarter. I mean, the -- I think when you first got into this, the business with NetScaler, there was some criticism. I had some criticisms. I'm concerned that there was a high concentration that NetScaler sold to cloud providers and -- but now this turns out to be -- looks to be any way, a good thing. You've typically said that this is going to be really lumpy going forward. But as you just pointed out, we've seen 9 months of pretty strong results here. I'm just curious if now your view on that has changed and is now -- this looks more to be a trend versus just sort of pretty lumpy business.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I call it slightly volatile more than lumpy, but it's -- it is still concentrated into a couple of hundred cloud providers, with the top 50 being very, very large household names, of course. I think that it's just a reflection of the meta-trend that'
componenttext: Yes, I call it slightly volatile more than lumpy, but it's -- it is still concentrated into a couple of hundred cloud providers, with the top 50 being very, very large household names, of course. I think that it's just a reflection of the meta-trend that's going on across our industry, around cloud and cloud build-out. So there's -- I wouldn't call it an insatiable appetite for capacity, but it's been extreme. And so there will continue to be some quarter-to-quarter volatility. I think that should be the expectation. But overall, it's a really important segment for us and one that we expect to see solid growth in for the full year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I might, a follow-up to Walter's question. Because I noticed on the cash flow statement, cash paid for licensing agreements and technology, which I'm not sure what -- it's usually a small number. This quarter was $24.3 million, which is, I th
componenttext: Okay. And if I might, a follow-up to Walter's question. Because I noticed on the cash flow statement, cash paid for licensing agreements and technology, which I'm not sure what -- it's usually a small number. This quarter was $24.3 million, which is, I think, more than 2x it was all of last year. There's usually a little bit in there every quarter. And I'm just curious if that had any impact as to why R&D was lower and maybe you can explain that a bit just like what is in there, especially the big jump this quarter.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Not a lot to explain. I mean, there's always different things we're doing from an inbound licensing point of view, asset purchases, technology purchases and other M&A. And those are generally the 4 buckets of one-off items that shown into R&D. Not a
componenttext: Yes. Not a lot to explain. I mean, there's always different things we're doing from an inbound licensing point of view, asset purchases, technology purchases and other M&A. And those are generally the 4 buckets of one-off items that shown into R&D. Not a reflection on why OpEx was higher or lower, really a nonrelated item.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, why did it jump this quarter, though? What is in -- like, what was special this quarter that it would jump to 2x than what it was the last year? And it's usually a pretty steady at low single-digit millions.
componenttext: Well, why did it jump this quarter, though? What is in -- like, what was special this quarter that it would jump to 2x than what it was the last year? And it's usually a pretty steady at low single-digit millions.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did a onetime licensing agreement for a technology that will become an entitlement for our customers on subscription and maintenance.
componenttext: Yes, we did a onetime licensing agreement for a technology that will become an entitlement for our customers on subscription and maintenance.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we shouldn't expect that going forward to go back to sort of low single digits of millions? I mean, there might be something like that happening, but generally?
componenttext: So we shouldn't expect that going forward to go back to sort of low single digits of millions? I mean, there might be something like that happening, but generally?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, generally, back to what it has been.
componenttext: Yes, generally, back to what it has been.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Scott Zeller from Needham & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Scott Zeller from Needham & Company.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another question on XenApp. There have been several, but I believe we'd heard over the past year or so of the development and that was mentioned in the prepared remarks, the 2 to 3 years of development. And wondered if this is really a refresh cycle more
componenttext: Another question on XenApp. There have been several, but I believe we'd heard over the past year or so of the development and that was mentioned in the prepared remarks, the 2 to 3 years of development. And wondered if this is really a refresh cycle more than anything else. Could you add some color around that? Because it seemed that I think before the investment and the rewrite, we'd heard that it had not been touched for, I believe, 5 or 8 years. So is this actually a refresh cycle?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's the refresh cycles from two vectors. It is absolutely technology refresh cycle from Citrix point of view. There was massive engineering efforts conducted over the last few years as we mentioned earlier that resulted in this highly scalable, h
componenttext: I think it's the refresh cycles from two vectors. It is absolutely technology refresh cycle from Citrix point of view. There was massive engineering efforts conducted over the last few years as we mentioned earlier that resulted in this highly scalable, highly performing solution that is built on single platform with highly performing patented protocol. That's one angle and that certainly drives adoption. On the other angle, there is Windows 10 phenomenon in the enterprise that essentially drives sort of reinvigoration of desire to put traditional apps -- legacy apps, for lack of a better word, into the modern desktops or deliver more than desktops through XenDesktop to the legacy hardware. Both trends would be playing here in the future without a doubt.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow up. Any comments about your initial thoughts you've given on fiscal '17, previously, the 30% operating margin and 4% to 5% top line?
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow up. Any comments about your initial thoughts you've given on fiscal '17, previously, the 30% operating margin and 4% to 5% top line?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't updated that '17 numbers. And we really aren't planning to until we get further in the year. Just the one comment that I made earlier. Obviously, we're tracking ahead of our prior guidance when it comes to operating leverage. We feel good a
componenttext: No, we haven't updated that '17 numbers. And we really aren't planning to until we get further in the year. Just the one comment that I made earlier. Obviously, we're tracking ahead of our prior guidance when it comes to operating leverage. We feel good about all the progress we're making there.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Michael Turits from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Michael Turits from Raymond James.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's James Wesman sitting in for Michael. First question for Kirill or David, can you just talk about the competitive environment in desktop versus VMware this quarter and your other competitors? And I have a follow-up for David on NetScaler.
componenttext: It's James Wesman sitting in for Michael. First question for Kirill or David, can you just talk about the competitive environment in desktop versus VMware this quarter and your other competitors? And I have a follow-up for David on NetScaler.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, competition continues and the competition, very strong. And it is highly competitive environment. As we shared, we have seen some good strong winds and I'm quite excited about those. And we see customers who really want to work with us, c
componenttext: Well, obviously, competition continues and the competition, very strong. And it is highly competitive environment. As we shared, we have seen some good strong winds and I'm quite excited about those. And we see customers who really want to work with us, customers who love our unified story, customers who love our capability. There was one particular one that I would mention that I had a chance to sit down, Friday, actually, in Paris. It's a large financial institution. They've just selected XenDesktop over VMware, VDI for 2 main reasons. One was overall cost of ownership and implementation; and two was capabilities and set of scenarios that only Citrix could support. And in particular, they discovered their proof of concept that only Citrix solution can support all broad range of peripherals that they wanted to run for virtualized desktop and that drove them to us. And that's just one example of many that we've seen, but at the same time, it's a competitive environment. We see our competitors discounting their solutions heavily. And in many cases, it's a combat. But we're here to win.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And David, a follow up on NetScaler. I know several people have been asking this, but just given that the recent success of it in Internet cloud providers and the business overall, you've grown the top line and license double digits plus for the la
componenttext: Great. And David, a follow up on NetScaler. I know several people have been asking this, but just given that the recent success of it in Internet cloud providers and the business overall, you've grown the top line and license double digits plus for the last 9 months or so. Do you feel like this is a sustainable growth rate into 2016? Should we be thinking that this is a double-digit grower going forward?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're obviously being conservative and cautious when we provide forward outlook. We're incredibly happy with the business over the last -- well, really over the last 10 years. But as you pointed out, the last 9 months have been particularly strong. A
componenttext: Yes, we're obviously being conservative and cautious when we provide forward outlook. We're incredibly happy with the business over the last -- well, really over the last 10 years. But as you pointed out, the last 9 months have been particularly strong. And so we're clearly taking share. Share is not broken out in terms of individual segments, but we took several points of share last year. I think we've got the capabilities to do that going forward. If you look across our product portfolio, we've got a unique technology approach where we are a software company. And that gives us capability to deliver these types of technologies in the form factor of an appliance, a highly virtualized appliance in a software package or via cloud consumption. And I think that gives us the ability to do some really unique things with customers that are going to play very, very well with all the meta-trends that are going on around us.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Philip Winslow from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Philip Winslow from Credit Suisse.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the XenApp and XenDesktop Workspace Suite side, I mean, you talked about obviously, the back-end infrastructure, the upgrade that you had, but also the recent releases where you're adding back end, call it, front-end capability as well.
componenttext: Just going back to the XenApp and XenDesktop Workspace Suite side, I mean, you talked about obviously, the back-end infrastructure, the upgrade that you had, but also the recent releases where you're adding back end, call it, front-end capability as well. And then obviously, with Workspace Suite, bundling in the XenMobile capabilities. Then you guys talked about just sort of the messaging to the channel and how it was back on track beginning last year it was building. So I guess, as you sort of balance these -- all of these together, are we past the point where sort of there are sort of no product issues and people are kind of ready to go in terms of upgrading the back end? And similarly, where -- it's like, if there had been confusion in the past in the channel, are we kind of complete there, too, and this is sort of the run rate to expect or is there another lay that still needs to build here in terms of the turnaround?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think refocusing on the restructuring efforts are clearly paying off. And the feedback that we're getting from the channel from customers and even from our own sellers has been resoundingly positive. I would say our sweet message resonates incredi
componenttext: Well, I think refocusing on the restructuring efforts are clearly paying off. And the feedback that we're getting from the channel from customers and even from our own sellers has been resoundingly positive. I would say our sweet message resonates incredibly well because this is precisely what customers want to implement. Our latest releases are very strong, XenApp, XenDesktop 7.8 has richness of functionality and lots of features that our competitors simply missing. At the same time, they're clearly providing this integrated environment. XenMobile 10.3, our latest release in that area, is very competitive, and we saw some very interesting takeouts with application management, on mobile application management being the core strength area of ours. And that's, again, the case where XenMobile working together with NetScaler working together with ShareFile, provides this unique better together scenario, and those are simply unmatched by competitors. So I think this is the case where we have something unique in our hands. Of course, there's always more things we need to do. Of course, we'll continue to evolve our solution and we will continue to invest in continuous research and development to add those new unique scenarios and embrace the needs of sort of new modern infrastructures and health enterprise move with the trends of sort of digital transformation. But we fell very good with where we are and very energized about the future.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's great. And then David, just a follow-up for you. I mean, in terms just the cost savings from the realignment you've done, obviously, you talked about in the past, a certain percentage actually bleeding into the next year sort of just a quar
componenttext: Got it. That's great. And then David, just a follow-up for you. I mean, in terms just the cost savings from the realignment you've done, obviously, you talked about in the past, a certain percentage actually bleeding into the next year sort of just a quarter into 2016 here. Any sort of change on that split of when these cost savings start showing up '16 versus '17?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's -- a lot of the short-term actions or things that we executed at the end of Q4 and into Q1, those are around people-related items. The longer-term items, the big structural things like bringing down facilities' capacity and optimizing the
componenttext: No, I think it's -- a lot of the short-term actions or things that we executed at the end of Q4 and into Q1, those are around people-related items. The longer-term items, the big structural things like bringing down facilities' capacity and optimizing there, which, up-to-date, we've touched about 27 facilities, which is over 20% of the overall portfolio. Those things have long-term tails on them, but they're also permanent benefits. Changes to our procurement, sourcing our organizations, things like that, that will be layering in gradually over time. Plus just the elimination of other types of events and programs and projects, et cetera. These things will layer in. I think the teams are running full out right now in terms of execution capacity. And as I've said a couple of times, we're a little ahead of our internal plan on the time line there. But I think we'll just keep focused on that. More to do.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kirk Materne from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kirk Materne from Evercore ISI.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Patrick Falzon on for Kirk. David, you kind of touched on this before, but on the strength in the U.S., was there anything from a macro competitive backdrop any different versus prior quarter? Or is it do you think this is really just about
componenttext: It's actually Patrick Falzon on for Kirk. David, you kind of touched on this before, but on the strength in the U.S., was there anything from a macro competitive backdrop any different versus prior quarter? Or is it do you think this is really just about you and your channel partners executing better?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that from a macro standpoint, I mean, Q1 always tends to be a little different than Q4. I mean, most organizations are still finalizing the locking down budgets. They're absorbing the uplift of purchases that they incurred in Q4. So it tends
componenttext: Well, I think that from a macro standpoint, I mean, Q1 always tends to be a little different than Q4. I mean, most organizations are still finalizing the locking down budgets. They're absorbing the uplift of purchases that they incurred in Q4. So it tends to start out a little bit slower, and that's just very, very typical across IT buying patterns. So I'd say Q1 was as expected. U.S., we're executing well. The teams are doing well, as I pointed out a couple of times. Competition, as Kirill said, is very strong in all regions. I think we've seen a high level of discounting from a lot of vendors. We've seen a high level of bundling, which is kind of a different type of discounting and that's persistent. So very competitive. Customers are very focused on the big same themes: cloud, mobility, security, et cetera, ways to simplify their own infrastructure. And so at this point, I would just call it execution.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Steve Ashley from Robert Baird.
componenttext: Next question comes from Steve Ashley from Robert Baird.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to ask about the channel. I think a lot of the discussions of ours has been on the products, but I know that making changes in the channel was an important part of the recent quarter. Just like to ask you to maybe call out what you think are some
componenttext: I'd like to ask about the channel. I think a lot of the discussions of ours has been on the products, but I know that making changes in the channel was an important part of the recent quarter. Just like to ask you to maybe call out what you think are some of the bigger or more important things that might have changed here in the first quarter.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, channel plays hugely important role in our future success and has been part of our go-to-market strategy for many years. I think every time you have a large and vibrant channel like we have, adding elements that help reinvigorate it and e
componenttext: Well, obviously, channel plays hugely important role in our future success and has been part of our go-to-market strategy for many years. I think every time you have a large and vibrant channel like we have, adding elements that help reinvigorate it and encourage growth is something that you need to continuously do. And that's precisely what we've done and communicated in the last quarter. It's basically program that encourages acceleration of customer adds and growth in the business and essentially, rewarding our channel partners for doing more of that.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steve, we're still -- I mean, we're still working our way through that. There's more work to do from a channel standpoint. We're getting the message out and aligning training and certifications, everything else. But in terms of an early data point tha
componenttext: And Steve, we're still -- I mean, we're still working our way through that. There's more work to do from a channel standpoint. We're getting the message out and aligning training and certifications, everything else. But in terms of an early data point that's positive, I mean, aggregate contribution from our reseller. The reseller part of our channel was up north of 10% Q1-to-Q1. So I mean, we're seeing good vibrancy in that respect. And then contribution from the really large named partners was up substantially higher than that. So strong quarter from an SI point of view.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terrific. And then another thing that you talked about in terms of go-to-market was maybe doing some more targeting of the mid-market and really trying to make an extended effort to reach out. Any update there? Is that something that has begun here in the
componenttext: Terrific. And then another thing that you talked about in terms of go-to-market was maybe doing some more targeting of the mid-market and really trying to make an extended effort to reach out. Any update there? Is that something that has begun here in the first quarter?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, early days. But we know that's going to be a combination of both go-to-market and end product. So some of the product areas that we've talked about, releasing in Q1 like the browser server, which gives really businesses of all size, but targeted towa
componenttext: Yes, early days. But we know that's going to be a combination of both go-to-market and end product. So some of the product areas that we've talked about, releasing in Q1 like the browser server, which gives really businesses of all size, but targeted towards mid-market in many dimensions, the ability to deliver browser-based apps, while managing performance, security, browser compatibility, et cetera, in a more simplified fashion. Consumption across areas like CSP that's been growing so quickly. Targeted towards that smaller and midsized customer and where they can consume cloud services and not have to manage the infrastructure. I mean, those are all trends moving in that direction. But in terms of the go-to-market efforts, we're just getting going on that front, and you should expect more through the balance of the year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I would add one very important element about strategy and execution as it relates to ShareFile, which has been fantastic solution for mid-market and essentially optimized for mid-markets with -- and SMB, essentially, with its cloud-based, self-
componenttext: Right. And I would add one very important element about strategy and execution as it relates to ShareFile, which has been fantastic solution for mid-market and essentially optimized for mid-markets with -- and SMB, essentially, with its cloud-based, self-serve delivery model. And now as ShareFile becomes very integral -- integrated part of the portfolio, those ingredients from the product side and those characteristics on self-service, easy-to-deploy type methodologies is starting to resonate across Citrix and we certainly expect to see more of that happening to the rest of the portfolio, which from the product side will position us much better in the SMB segment with the cloud delivery model.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz from Cowen & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz from Cowen & Company.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, when I called that out, it was just specifically in a quarter 1 to quarter 1 comparison not because there was some seasonality that moves around it. componenttext: Okay. And then on the NetScaler market share, I believe what you said in the past is that you do expect your NetScaler business to grow in line with or faster than the market in 2016. Based on how you've started the year from an execution standpoint, has your level of optimism increased as it relates to market share gains going forward?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're certainly happy with the performance of Q1 and optimistic about our ability to execute for the balance of the year. So I'm optimistic about this business for sure.
componenttext: We're certainly happy with the performance of Q1 and optimistic about our ability to execute for the balance of the year. So I'm optimistic about this business for sure.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: There are additional elements to this business that are also quite interesting, in particular in SD-WAN, which is new unique capability that we have added in pure software-delivered fashion. componenttext: This is Sanjit Singh in for Keith. Wanted to go back to the Workspace Services division. When we talked about overall license growth being flat, I guess my question here is how much does -- to what percentage does -- do we even get to in terms of the CSP business and the Workspace Services business as a percentage to get that license growth to start to accelerate into the low to positive -- low to mid-single-digit license growth?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's not just a function of what percentage that has to get to because that's a two-variable equation. But I'd say that overall, we're working on growing all elements that business. I called out a few statistics earlier. But the fact that in the agg
componenttext: Well, it's not just a function of what percentage that has to get to because that's a two-variable equation. But I'd say that overall, we're working on growing all elements that business. I called out a few statistics earlier. But the fact that in the aggregate, we are approaching 20% coming from subscription, which was 14% a year ago. That's the direction this business will continue to move over time, plus all the work that Kirill and I have talked about around the product area, just addressing some broader trends in the industry, making the products more integrated and everything that we're doing to drive on the fully baked suite approach on the top stem. So I think it's a combination of all those. Clearly, we see this as a business that needs to grow, and we're working really hard to make it into a sustainable growth business on the license line.

And also from a strategic point of view, is there anything that needs to be refined strategically, given the healthier state of the business as we look at it today?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say strategically, I mean, we're starting to talk a little bit more about that and come -- we'll invite you to come and join us at our Analyst Day at Synergy at the end of May. We'll be talking much more about overall Citrix strategy and how to
componenttext: Well, I'd say strategically, I mean, we're starting to talk a little bit more about that and come -- we'll invite you to come and join us at our Analyst Day at Synergy at the end of May. We'll be talking much more about overall Citrix strategy and how to think about that going forward. In terms of revenue outperformance, clearly, that's been driving an acceleration of our margin goals. We're fully on target for delivering that 30%-plus year before too long and that's not going to change. We're always investing in things that we believe are going to drive long-term growth. And I think that's our responsibility to make sure we're investing in just those things that are aligned tightly to the strategy, very focused and have the highest probability of return. As we see those, we'll be investing in those. The reason why we've gone through so much hard work on the restructuring is that it frees up the capital to be able to do that and deliver the upside the margins on an ongoing basis. So that's the goal.

componenttext: I had the question about Windows 10 and a potential upgrade cycle in the enterprise. How you look at that as really an opportunity to kind of reintroduce some of your newer products and new offerings and whether you see that impacting the demand profile in your core customer base.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good question, and obviously, we see Windows 10 as a huge opportunity. It's a reality in the enterprise, and we see enterprise upgrade accelerating to Windows 10. And Citrix has a very important role to play in that, very important role on del
componenttext: Yes. It's a good question, and obviously, we see Windows 10 as a huge opportunity. It's a reality in the enterprise, and we see enterprise upgrade accelerating to Windows 10. And Citrix has a very important role to play in that, very important role on delivering apps to Windows 10 desktops that people and organizations just bring and upgrade by themselves, but at the same time, giving IT professionals and infrastructure managers the ability to deliver managed and controlled Windows 10 desktops to -- in a sort of more controlled and regulated environments. And I think both of that -- both of those are very important trends. And our customers are telling us that this is really sort of, I would say, very significant sort of beginning of that upgrade cycle that we certainly look forward to participating.

componenttext: Well, if you're getting a suite, you're getting both.
