componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Doris, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Systems' Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Mr. Eduardo Fleites, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doris, and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's second quarter 2016 earnings presentation. Participating on the call will be Kirill Tatarinov, President and CEO; and David Henshall, Chief Operating Officer and CFO.
componenttext:
Thank you, Doris, and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's second quarter 2016 earnings presentation. Participating on the call will be Kirill Tatarinov, President and CEO; and David Henshall, Chief Operating Officer and CFO. This call is being webcast on Citrix Systems' Investor Relations website. The webcast will be posted immediately following the call. 
Before we begin, I want to state that we have posted product specification and historical revenue trends related to our product groupings to our Investor Relations website.
I'd like to remind you that today's conversation will contain forward-looking statements made under the safe harbor provision of the U.S. securities law. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Obviously, these risks could cause actual results to differ from those anticipated. Additional information concerning these and other factors is highlighted in today's press release and in the company's filings with the SEC. Copies are available from the SEC or on the company's Investor Relations website.
Further more, we will discuss various non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC's Reg G. A reconciliation of the differences between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures discussed on today's call can be found at the end of today's press release and on the Investor Relations page of our website. Now I'd like to turn it over to David Henshall, our COO and CFO. David?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us today. We continue to show great results from the operational initiatives we introduced last year. We are focusing all of our energy on our core strategy of securely delivering apps and data, allowing fo
componenttext:
Thanks, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us today. We continue to show great results from the operational initiatives we introduced last year. We are focusing all of our energy on our core strategy of securely delivering apps and data, allowing for this consistent execution and really setting the company up for profitable growth as we look forward.
And as you can see from the release, total revenue was up 6% year-on-year in Q2, with product license up 7% and SaaS up 14%. Adjusted operating margin was 28%. Adjusted EPS was $1.20 per share, up 20% from Q2 a year ago, and we also generated $228 million in cash flow from operations. 
In total, we closed 61 $1 million-plus transactions across products and services, an increase of 33% year-on-year, with particular strength coming from financial services, health care and cloud verticals. There's also a good balance across the portfolio. More than half of these transactions coming from Workspace Services solutions, the increasing number from Delivery Networking and even our largest-ever single contract around Enterprise file, sync and share. 
From a geo perspective, excluding the GoTo business, revenue from the Americas was up 11% while EMEA and APJ both declined modestly. The Americas geo has continued to really be the growth engine for a number quarters now. This region is where our restructuring activities began over the last year, and therefore has had the benefit of stability and continuity, a key contributor to this performance and a model for changes that we're making elsewhere in the world.
So next, let's look at our Q2 results within our primary groups. Our Workspace Services business, including app virtualization and mobility grew about 2% to $412 million, including a 1% year-on-year increase in license revenue. The results show that this business is benefiting from the strategy and increased focus applied last year. And as we've discussed before, there's a number of specific initiatives that we're driving to accelerate growth in this area through faster innovation, more verticalized solutions and aggregation of our unique assets. Within this area, there's a few dynamics that are worth noting. First, total revenue from the Workspace suite, which is our comprehensive solution for secure app and data delivery, was up more than 70%, contributed about 12% of license revenue.
Second, we continue to grow our CSP subscriptions, where partners primarily utilize XenApp to deliver cloud-based offerings to their customers. Overall, CSP revenue grew 37% to an ARR of about $75 million. And finally, we saw great results coming out of the Americas geo for overall Workspace Services, where license revenue grew 23% in the quarter and 16% for the first half, really led by demand from the suite.
Next looking at our Delivery Networking. Total revenue increased 11% in the quarter to $195 million, with license growth of 16%. When you focus just on NetScaler, I'll remind everybody that the business is essentially made up of 3 segments: cloud infrastructure and service providers, Citrix solution sales and Enterprise ADC. Demand from the cloud customers continues to be really strong, consistent with what we've seen over the past year. This segment contributed about half of NetScaler product bookings. 
Solution attached sales represented 15% of the mix in Q2, with a number of app and mobile opportunities that included networking as part of an overall Citrix solution, consistent with what we saw a year ago. 
Enterprise ADC was about 1/3 of the mix in Q2, and we're seeing an increased traction from the new NetScaler SD-WAN products, which is addressing a nascent market but one that's expected to grow really significantly over the next few years. All in, we sold over 1,900 networking customers in the period with over 1/3 of them being net new. 
And finally, our SaaS-delivered revenue was up 14%, contributing over $200 million in the quarter. The contribution from the GoTo solutions was $169 million, growing 10.5% from a year ago. As we announced earlier today, we're merging this business with LogMeIn over the next few quarters. But until that transaction is completed, we'll continue to operate as a consolidated entity for reporting and guidance purposes. More detail on the performance of the GoTo business' individual segments will be included in the LogMeIn S-4 filing, which is expected later this quarter.
Looking back on the other core Citrix cloud-based services, it contributed $33 million in total revenue, growing at 30%. The bulk of this is coming from ShareFile, our secure data platform, and other new services addressing mobile networking and desktop needs for our customers.
So clearly, we're beginning to see a shift in the way that products are being consumed by our customers, evolving slowly towards a more consumption-based model. When we include revenue coming from the CSP program, our cloud-based services, excluding GoTo, and any term licenses, the aggregate ARR was over $200 million in Q2, growing at more than 30%. We'll begin to break this out each quarter to provide more visibility into this dynamic.
Shifting gears and turning to operations. We've shown a rapid increase in margin over the last few quarters despite funding incremental investments in our growth businesses and certain go-to-market areas. Our restructuring plans across the company are intended to generate permanent expense reductions, allowing the company to execute more efficiently, while also driving scalability into the future.
In Q2, we posted 28% adjusted op margin, which was up 370 basis points from a year ago. We're clearly operating well ahead of our stated goal of reaching 30% in the fiscal year '17. 
The focus on leverage has also really helped increase cash flow from operations, which was up 13% in the quarter to $228 million and up 31% on a trailing 12-month basis. This translates into approximately $1.46 per share in the quarter and over $7 a share over the last 4 quarters.
Before I wrap up, let me talk about our current outlook and expectations for the remainder of the year. Our operational programs and strategy is clearly working, and we're happy with the results and confident in our plans for the balance of the year. At the same time, we're going to remain conservative given the restructuring, the GoTo merger and the significant revenue upside that we delivered in the first half of this year. That said, we're going to increase our assumptions for Q3 and for the full year.
For Q3 '16, we now expect revenue in the range of $820 million to $830 million and adjusted EPS of between $1.18 and $1.20 per share. For the full year 2016, we're increasing our expectations to include revenue between $3.37 billion and $3.39 billion, and adjusted EPS of $5 and $5.10 per share. This range represents 3% to 4% growth on the top line and more than 15% growth in adjusted EPS. We remind you that this guidance represents all businesses, including those that are part of the planned GoTo merger. 
So now I'd like to turn it over to Kirill to give you further color on the quarter and the focus on areas looking forward. Kirill?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. I'm very encouraged by our performance this quarter. It's a clear signal that our focused execution on the strategy to deliver the world's best integrated technology services for secure delivery of apps and data is resonating well with o
componenttext:
Thank you, David. I'm very encouraged by our performance this quarter. It's a clear signal that our focused execution on the strategy to deliver the world's best integrated technology services for secure delivery of apps and data is resonating well with our customers, partners and the market. 
Our product teams have delivered on all commitments, enabling us to make a number of powerful announcement at the Synergy event in late May. Specifically, we announced and delivered XenApp XenDesktop 7.9, new NetScaler with an option to deliver in a docket container and also brand new management and analytics system in NetScaler, and also ShareFile's new information rights management, amongst many other advanced capabilities. 
We've also announced our renewed and stronger-than-ever partnership with Microsoft. And most importantly, we shared our strategy to become the leader in Workspace-as-a-Service and accelerate our move to the cloud. All these announcements and product delivery received resoundingly positive feedback from all constituencies. Our innovation and partnerships are clearly fueling the continued strength in our execution and position us as #1 or 2 in all market segments where we play. 
Adding some comments to the Q2 results that David just shared. I'm very pleased to see that our Workspace Services business, or Xen family, is delivering growth, reversing past trends and clearly regaining market share. This quarter, our rate of growth in net new customers for XenApp/XenDesktop reached strong double-digit growth year-over-year. 
XenMobile contributed strongly to the overall suite. Last month, Citrix was yet again positioned as a leader in Gartner's Magic Quadrant for Enterprise Mobility Management Suites. 
On our transformation to the cloud. The growth in ShareFile reached 30% year-over-year in new sales, and our Citrix service provided business continues to grow at a rapid pace, 37 percentage points year-over-year, primarily delivering XenApp and XenDesktop as a cloud service but also now adding XenMobile and NetScaler as cloud service as well. We clearly see that the cloud is a strong growth catalyst for Citrix, really positive sign as we continue to focus on the evolving Citrix cloud strategy. Overall, this was a terrific quarter for our worldwide sales team, particularly our Americas team executed extremely well in the quarter. 
We just completed a comprehensive review of our operations in EMEA, and we see strong opportunities in the region, of course, balancing it with other geopolitical headwinds. We've seen some strong winds in Asia Pacific and Japan, and we have high growth aspirations for that region also. This was an incredible quarter adding new customers to the Citrix family, but also solidifying our existing customer relationships. We also saw significant growth in large deals, as David mentioned, and we saw strengths in our targeted industry verticals, particularly financial services and health care with nearly 1/3 of our largest wins represented by health care organizations. 
A significant number of customers are moving from other virtualization and networking vendors to Citrix. In fact, we have nearly 800 combined competitive wins or replacements against our top competitors in Q2. Amongst more noticeable competitive wins in Q2, Kindred health network, a long-time competitor's customer with more than 12,000 employees and 2,100 physicians, chose XenDesktop for VDI deployment. In another win, a major short-term housing provider in the United States selected Citrix cloud delivered XenApp and XenDesktop to support business-critical applications in more than 180 locations. This win serves a nice example of XenApp and XenDesktop returning to growth and regaining market share. 
Our renewed strength in Microsoft partnership started to bear fruit already in this past quarter. We'll work with Microsoft on an engagement with a cellular carrier owned by LG Corporation. It was the largest-ever deal closed in Korea for Citrix with 29,000 licenses being deployed to help enhance security and productivity. 
On strengthening our existing customer relationships, one of the world's largest investment banks, a long-standing XenApp and XenDesktop took customer moved to allow Citrix to its worldwide operations, encompassing more than 200,000 employees. The bank's decision to choose Citrix was heavily influenced by our unique ability to execute virtualized Skype for Business, and this was only 1 of many such examples. Microsoft recently issued a technical guidance, making an ambiguous statement that Citrix is the clear choice for deploying Skype for Business in virtualized environments. We anticipate that our partnership and alignment with Microsoft will provide us continued additional lift in end user computing. 
On the network delivery side, CMA Insurance, one of the largest commercial insurance companies in the United States replaced and established competitive networking vendor with Citrix NetScaler, making it the cornerstone for their networking infrastructure. CMA chose NetScaler to provide with quality end user experience to their employees and the mission-critical applications. Essentially, it is an ADC scenario in the Enterprise.
And finally, ShareFile continues to provide itself as an industry leader, quickly gaining share in the market. We're seeing our efforts to extend ShareFile to the Enterprise segment paid big dividends with the highest number of large deals ever. Among those large-scale wins with ShareFile, we saw one of the largest accounting firms standardized on ShareFile to enable secure collaboration and workflows between their consultants and the clients. With accounting being a target vertical for ShareFile, this win now gives ShareFile 2 of the top of 4 accounting firms as customers. 
Our unique differentiators clearly help ShareFile to continue stand out against generic cloud storage providers. In fact, last week, Citrix was positioned as a leader in Gartner's Magic Quadrant for Enterprise file, sync and share for the third consecutive year. Needless to say, we see very bright future for ShareFile. 
This week marks my sixth month as Citrix CEO, and I'm more enthusiastic than ever. Our results demonstrate that we're on the right path, building new Citrix. I feel highly confident that we have the right strategy and the plan to execute upon it. I'm incredibly excited about the future of Citrix. Today's announcement with LogMeIn will allow us to continue to focus our resources and investments and accelerate our execution and results. Thank you, and we look forward to your questions.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Walter Pritchard with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Walter Pritchard with Citi.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, maybe just a quick one for David on maintenance revenue was down sequentially. We haven't seen that before. What was the driver there?
componenttext: Two questions. One, maybe just a quick one for David on maintenance revenue was down sequentially. We haven't seen that before. What was the driver there?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Walt. 2 things. One is the decrease is a direct result of just declining Workspace Services license you've seen a couple of years back. And unfortunately, the pressure there is abating. Hence, the performance has really come back on that front. I'd
componenttext: Sure, Walt. 2 things. One is the decrease is a direct result of just declining Workspace Services license you've seen a couple of years back. And unfortunately, the pressure there is abating. Hence, the performance has really come back on that front. I'd say that as we've talked about a couple of times, we're uplifting the ARR by delivering new offerings and really migrating customers towards higher-value subscriptions. And so as of last quarter, we had about 25% of the installed base migrated. We're going to be make a larger portion in the second half of the year, really accelerating that. So I think that's one of the things that's going to continue to drive license update and maintenance going forward. I'd say the second thing is a little bit of a timing issue with our largest installed base customer for an order that came in right after the close of the quarter, which influenced that to a kind of a mid-single-digit millions range. Overall, when I look at license update and maintenance line, comfortable with about 3% growth for the year and expect that to grow sequentially into Q3.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Kirill, on the GetGo transaction, you're contributing about 2/3 of the revenue to that business and you're taking about half of the economic value there in terms of the shares after the deal. And I'm wondering just sort of how you thought about t
componenttext: And then Kirill, on the GetGo transaction, you're contributing about 2/3 of the revenue to that business and you're taking about half of the economic value there in terms of the shares after the deal. And I'm wondering just sort of how you thought about that. It seems like a bit favored in your direction on the revenue contribution, but more of an even split on the economics.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you think about this deal, first and foremost, this transaction is about synergies, then it's about scale. Essentially, we're creating a new company, which is at scale, at much larger scale compared to both LogMeIn and GetGo, if we were to spin i
componenttext: Well, if you think about this deal, first and foremost, this transaction is about synergies, then it's about scale. Essentially, we're creating a new company, which is at scale, at much larger scale compared to both LogMeIn and GetGo, if we were to spin it off into the independent company. And most importantly, there's a speed of execution and certainty for Citrix. I think those 3 things combined, in particular the Synergy side, which realizes tremendous value for both LogMeIn and Citrix, is a tremendous asset here. We have larger revenue, LogMeIn is a faster-growing company. In balance, we feel good about the distribution of value in this transaction.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from the line of Kash Rangan with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question is from the line of Kash Rangan with Bank of America.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is Nikolay Beliov sitting in for Kash. Kirill, maybe can you give us a little bit more detail around the Microsoft relationship, especially the go-to-market component of it?
componenttext: It is Nikolay Beliov sitting in for Kash. Kirill, maybe can you give us a little bit more detail around the Microsoft relationship, especially the go-to-market component of it?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Obviously, as you all know, we've announced this much stronger relationship at the end of May, along with our Synergy conference. We're now putting it to work. There's a tremendous collaboration that we're starting to see in the field worldwide. I ju
componenttext: Yes. Obviously, as you all know, we've announced this much stronger relationship at the end of May, along with our Synergy conference. We're now putting it to work. There's a tremendous collaboration that we're starting to see in the field worldwide. I just returned from touring EMEA. And every step of the way, there is a lot of energy and a lot of discussion between Microsoft and Citrix field organizations. We've seen some real examples where collaboration is already occurring. LG U+ in Korea was one such example and there are many more, and I would expect to see a lot more. This is clearly the case where this is win-win for both companies. Citrix is truly helping Microsoft deploy Skype for Business in virtualized setting in the large enterprises, and that's how they want to deploy Skype for Business. This is also the case where Citrix has ready-to-go technology to help deploy Windows 10 in the Enterprise, and obviously Microsoft is very focused on that deployment. And all of that is even before we realized some additional product integrations that are coming later in the next 12 months, Enterprise Mobility Suite and NetScaler with Azure and more on Azure integration. So all in all, this is really what we're seeing as the beginning of this partnership becoming to work for both companies.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you please provide us an update with how the channel performed in the quarter?
componenttext: And can you please provide us an update with how the channel performed in the quarter?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Nikolay, it's David. I'd say channel continues to perform well. We've been working on that over the course of the last few quarters. You're seeing a higher contribution kind of the way we measure internally around net new source versus fulfillment. A
componenttext: Yes, Nikolay, it's David. I'd say channel continues to perform well. We've been working on that over the course of the last few quarters. You're seeing a higher contribution kind of the way we measure internally around net new source versus fulfillment. And so it's trending in the right direction.

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. If I look at your growth in Workspace, it's good, it's getting better but it still is very measured growth rate. And I look at the friends from the Amber [ph], and they -- you'll see numbers don't look overly pretty at the moment and let's
componenttext: Two questions. If I look at your growth in Workspace, it's good, it's getting better but it still is very measured growth rate. And I look at the friends from the Amber [ph], and they -- you'll see numbers don't look overly pretty at the moment and let's not talk about mobile. And for the time being, is there a change in how the value gets distributed in the industry at moment with Microsoft taking a bigger share or...? Something -- anyone -- all of the -- all big guys seem to be suffering at the moment, and it seems something bigger is going on. And maybe I'm missing something here, but maybe Kirill, maybe give me your view of how you think about this?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in the -- when you take the geography where our execution is really growing incredibly well, which is Americas, we clearly see winning, we clearly see Citrix taking share and we clearly see Citrix regaining strength. And I think our execution in N
componenttext: I think in the -- when you take the geography where our execution is really growing incredibly well, which is Americas, we clearly see winning, we clearly see Citrix taking share and we clearly see Citrix regaining strength. And I think our execution in North America and our growth in virtual computing and end user computing as a whole and North America is just an example of what's possible when the execution gets nailed across the world, which of course is something that we're focused on working on, and we'll see in the coming quarters. But the -- certainly, the tides have shifted in the last quarter. That's how we want to see it. I think our teams worldwide are getting very focused on regaining market share and getting to winning spirit. That's been a pretty significant shift that was saw and that is evidenced by just sheer volume of wins that we've seen around the world, but most importantly in North America. And of course, as I mentioned earlier, our partnership with Microsoft is starting to provide significant uplift, and we believe that it will continue to provide that uplift going forward.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Raimo, it's David. Let me put a few numbers around that as well just to reinforce a couple of these points. First off, as Kirill mentioned, Americas did extremely well. In fact, for Workspace Services new licenses, they posted over 20% growth year-on-year
componenttext: Raimo, it's David. Let me put a few numbers around that as well just to reinforce a couple of these points. First off, as Kirill mentioned, Americas did extremely well. In fact, for Workspace Services new licenses, they posted over 20% growth year-on-year. When I look at our subscription-delivered CSP business, that's growing north of 35% year-on-year. Our other SaaS-delivered options, while small, things like XenMobile cloud and others, are growing over 25% in the year. So we're certainly seeing user growth faster than actual reported revenue growth, but that's okay because those will catch up over a lifetime value. So we feel like the work that we've been over the course of last year, the innovation, the integration and simplification is really working on our favor and we'll just keep executing.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Nicole in for Heather. I might have missed this, but could you talk about the percent of delivery network revenue that came from public cloud vendors? And since this business is typically lumpy quarter-to-quarter, how do you expect this business t
componenttext: This is Nicole in for Heather. I might have missed this, but could you talk about the percent of delivery network revenue that came from public cloud vendors? And since this business is typically lumpy quarter-to-quarter, how do you expect this business to play out in the second half, especially given difficult comps starting next quarter?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nicole, this is David. We -- I did say that about 50% of the contribution in the quarter from NetScaler is coming from cloud infrastructure and cloud service providers. I mean, it continues to be, obviously, a meta trend across the industry. And so n
componenttext: Yes, Nicole, this is David. We -- I did say that about 50% of the contribution in the quarter from NetScaler is coming from cloud infrastructure and cloud service providers. I mean, it continues to be, obviously, a meta trend across the industry. And so not only are we contributing to the build-out of public cloud infrastructure, which has been a tremendous strength over the last 4 quarters, but we're seeing a growing number of customers that are actually delivering their own cloud services. And so that's part of expanding the base at the same time. It has been a little bit more of a lumpy segment historically. However, we're now on the fourth quarter of strength in this business. So we've had great continuity over the course of the last year. It's one of the things that always allow us to be conservative when we look forward because it is such a large concentration, but we love our position there. And when I look at the other parts of NetScaler, like the Enterprise ADC market, et cetera, we've talked about being capacity constrained in the past. One of the investments we're making right now is to expand our go-to-market capacity across, really, across all geos. And that's one of the things that will allow us to even accelerate that business going forward.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about this margin expansion from here in the core business. It's obviously been an unbelievable move over the last year, but I imagine some of the low-hanging fruits have been sort of pruned at this po
componenttext: David, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about this margin expansion from here in the core business. It's obviously been an unbelievable move over the last year, but I imagine some of the low-hanging fruits have been sort of pruned at this point in time. And what drives margin expansion from here? And then just secondly and somewhat related, when are we going to get a bit of a clearer view of the core business, margins and earnings contribution, say, ex the GoTo business? Is that something that's just got to wait till after the transaction's completed or, I guess, how are you thinking about that?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kirk. Let me start at the top, actually, just talk about op margins. So in -- 6 months ago, when we laid out targets for the combined company, we're talking about 30% op margin by the end of 2017, I mean, we're clearly operating well ahead of that,
componenttext: Sure, Kirk. Let me start at the top, actually, just talk about op margins. So in -- 6 months ago, when we laid out targets for the combined company, we're talking about 30% op margin by the end of 2017, I mean, we're clearly operating well ahead of that, probably nearly a full year in front of that when we look at our guidance. So we're really happy with execution across the board. When you kind of step back a little bit and think about the core Citrix, excluding the part of this merging, LogMeIn, that part of the business is operating between 1.5 and 2 percentage points higher on an adjusted op margin than the consolidated whole. So we're clearly well above the 30% range already from a core Citrix point of view. As it comes to providing more granularity into the individual pieces, the S-4 will be filed by LogMeIn later this quarter. And so at that point in time, you'll have better position to look at the individual performance of the GoTo business stand-alone, the forecast moving forward, et cetera. And I'd say, after Q3, we'll be talking about guidance going forward for 2017 as a stand-alone entity. So I'd say that's one way to think about it.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I actually just like to talk about the international business, maybe specifically EMEA. Kirill, you mentioned you were just over there. You mentioned that you've kind of just begun following the road map that the U.S. had provided, but I wonder if you cou
componenttext: I actually just like to talk about the international business, maybe specifically EMEA. Kirill, you mentioned you were just over there. You mentioned that you've kind of just begun following the road map that the U.S. had provided, but I wonder if you could just drill down and get a little bit more color on what can a changes we might see in EMEA, what kind of timing we're talking about? Could you give us a little bit more color around that?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we'd certainly seen tremendous progress in the Americas since we started the restructuring and implemented some very important changes in this region earlier than we did it in EMEA and in Asia Pacific and Japan. Essentially, we're following t
componenttext: Yes, I think we'd certainly seen tremendous progress in the Americas since we started the restructuring and implemented some very important changes in this region earlier than we did it in EMEA and in Asia Pacific and Japan. Essentially, we're following the same blueprint that is working so successfully for us in Americas. And in EMEA right now, this was the sort of the main purpose of deep dive with the team. In EMEA, we had the entire leadership for 2 days and we went through strategy across different countries across different regions. And we really see some positive momentum and we see great opportunities. In fact, we've spotted some strong opportunities in the U.K., and we're working to realize them. And we expect to see those materialize, I would say, within the next 12 months. Similarly in France, and we have strong leadership and strong execution in Germany and Central and Eastern Europe in place already. So we look forward to seeing greater results in that region. Overall, as I mentioned in my remarks, we see great opportunities there, obviously, balancing it with all those geopolitical headwinds. But I would think that in the next 12 months, we see stronger results in EMEA following what we've seen here in Americas already.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And just a quick follow-up on the NetScaler business, I was going to ask about service provider. I think one of the things you were trying to do is reduce the reliance on large transactions with maybe some of the customers concentration you have,
componenttext: Perfect. And just a quick follow-up on the NetScaler business, I was going to ask about service provider. I think one of the things you were trying to do is reduce the reliance on large transactions with maybe some of the customers concentration you have, trying to build out a more of a run rate business. Have you been able to do that? Is some of the strength we've seen here coming on base hits and doing some of that smaller business?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'd say overall, when looking at NetScaler, we sold to 1,900 unique customers in the period. About 1/3 of those being net new to Citrix. So a big push for us going forward is, of course, continuing to expand the base.
componenttext: Sure. I'd say overall, when looking at NetScaler, we sold to 1,900 unique customers in the period. About 1/3 of those being net new to Citrix. So a big push for us going forward is, of course, continuing to expand the base.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to drill down on one of the positive metrics here that 23% license growth in the Americas for the Workspace business. You broadly said it was due to good execution, but could you offer a little bit more clarity on how you're driving that gro
componenttext: I just wanted to drill down on one of the positive metrics here that 23% license growth in the Americas for the Workspace business. You broadly said it was due to good execution, but could you offer a little bit more clarity on how you're driving that growth? And whether pricing is a lever that you're using any more aggressively?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David. I'd say pricing is not a lever we're using aggressively. In fact, pricing is one of those things that you're competing against. In many cases, we are not the low-cost provider. In fact, we're -- you're often competing against a bundled solu
componenttext: This is David. I'd say pricing is not a lever we're using aggressively. In fact, pricing is one of those things that you're competing against. In many cases, we are not the low-cost provider. In fact, we're -- you're often competing against a bundled solution. And so price is not a lever that generates growth generally. We compete on breadth of functionality. We compete on integration and unique assets. And so that's really been the big driver. When you look across the Americas business, they had great performance from everything from fin services, to health care to technology companies and others. And it's just a testament to the execution of that team and a lot of the work that they've done. So I'd say our win rates and everything in the U.S. are extremely high, and we're just going to continue driving forward as quickly as we can.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael Turits. Maybe I'll ask about the desktop business, but how about on the XenMobile side? What do you see as the general market dynamics there? Do you still see this as a growth business with opportunity for penetration and pricing? And what are you
componenttext: Michael Turits. Maybe I'll ask about the desktop business, but how about on the XenMobile side? What do you see as the general market dynamics there? Do you still see this as a growth business with opportunity for penetration and pricing? And what are you seeing competitively against your watch, MobileIron and Microsoft?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we actually see XenMobile continue to perform well as part of the overall suite, as part of the overall Workspace suite and end user computing push from Citrix. As I mentioned, we've received another strong accolade from Gartner, being named as a lea
componenttext: Yes, we actually see XenMobile continue to perform well as part of the overall suite, as part of the overall Workspace suite and end user computing push from Citrix. As I mentioned, we've received another strong accolade from Gartner, being named as a leader in their Magic Quadrant, and the product has done very well. We have some unique differentiators that have continued to play out for us. In particular, we differentiate by delivering unique set of capabilities in mobile application management as opposed to just generic low-cost mobile device management. And these are the capabilities that are being valued in bring-your-own-device scenarios. These are capabilities that are actually being valued by Microsoft. They were core to our alignment with Microsoft between XenMobile and Enterprise Mobility suite. And we see continued strength and growth in that market. Yet again, we differentiate by focusing on mobile application management by delivering unique capabilities like MicroVPN and really focusing on a suite with XenMobile, with ShareFile and with NetScaler playing significant role in that particular rollout. And we also continue to strengthen our portfolio and our solution with some additional capabilities like the new Forms application that was introduced as part of XenMobile in June. It's being very well received by our customers yet again, focusing on applications versus device itself. So we're quite excited about what we have with XenMobile. We predominantly see it as a part of the overall suite, of the overall offering. We see more and more customers choosing XenMobile to be delivered to the cloud service, and we expect to see more of that. And we are quite excited and bullish about that particular product.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It sounds really strong in terms of capabilities. You did mention on -- you see that -- or desktop, it felt like you're regaining share there. Does it feel the same way on XenMobile, or is it hard to tell with this part of the bundle?
componenttext: It sounds really strong in terms of capabilities. You did mention on -- you see that -- or desktop, it felt like you're regaining share there. Does it feel the same way on XenMobile, or is it hard to tell with this part of the bundle?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really view it as part of the overall solution. And as David mentioned, we see significant growth, continuous growth, in customers wanting to buy the overall is suite and kind of the overall Citrix value as opposed to point products. And I think -- so
componenttext: We really view it as part of the overall solution. And as David mentioned, we see significant growth, continuous growth, in customers wanting to buy the overall is suite and kind of the overall Citrix value as opposed to point products. And I think -- so even if you look at sort of some of our competitors, we're ahead of many in sort of being able to provide this complete value, raising our standing in the enterprise IT to the level of the enterprise decision-maker versus point product implementer. And we actually view it as a very positive sign. We first sort of saw it at Synergy, when for the first time ever, we have this good contingent of IT decision-makers, really senior CIO level people coming to join us to talk about Citrix. And that raised profile and raised visibility, certainly enabled us to deliver more of that complete value, and that's certainly how we look at the future. It's not point product. It's overall end-to-end solution to help people securely deliver their apps and data.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Abhey Lamba with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Abhey Lamba with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now how should we think about the potential for Workspace's business in light of your partnership with Microsoft? What type of revenue growth can the segment deliver on a sustainable basis and how far are we from getting there?
componenttext: Now how should we think about the potential for Workspace's business in light of your partnership with Microsoft? What type of revenue growth can the segment deliver on a sustainable basis and how far are we from getting there?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our partnership with Microsoft is starting to produce real results. And in this past quarter already, even though we announced this partnership with Microsoft actually midway in the quarter, even in that quarter, we saw some very exciting wi
componenttext: Well, I think our partnership with Microsoft is starting to produce real results. And in this past quarter already, even though we announced this partnership with Microsoft actually midway in the quarter, even in that quarter, we saw some very exciting wins as a result of better alignment. We see more of that alignment coming in the future. I would say right now, we're at the beginning of working out the mechanics and specifics of how this partnership is going play out in the field. The signs, the early signs are incredibly positive, and we're certainly looking forward to increase velocity and better execution, and frankly, better  momentum as we work close together. There are some specific product initiatives and specific joint workings in the field that will certainly be producing more results. We're ready to go with Skype for Business virtualized, and that's how many large enterprises wanted to deploy Skype for Business on Citrix. Microsoft just issued technical guidance on -- essentially stating that Citrix is a clear choice to deploy Skype for Business this way. We have solution to deploy Windows 10 in the Enterprise in a virtualized and VDI fashion, and that is incredibly well received and that is a huge priority for Microsoft. And we certainly expect both of those existing initiatives to start bearing more fruit. Of course, it depends on overall Skype for Business adoption in the Enterprise. It all depends on Windows 10 adoption to Enterprise, and we continue to work with Microsoft to advance it. And of course, later in this year, we're really looking forward to introducing additional capabilities into this partnership and into this channel, especially with XenMobile and overall XenMobile suite now playing a role into the Enterprise mobility suite and also NetScaler being aligned with Azure.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And David, it looks like OpEx was a little bit more than initially expected, resulting in lesser EPS bid [ph] towards the revenue outperformance. Can you talk about the OpEx during the quarter? What drove it higher and how should it trend over the
componenttext: Got it. And David, it looks like OpEx was a little bit more than initially expected, resulting in lesser EPS bid [ph] towards the revenue outperformance. Can you talk about the OpEx during the quarter? What drove it higher and how should it trend over the next few quarters? That's it for me.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bob. I'd say that a few one-time costs in Q2, especially in the G&A line, you saw that jumped pretty heavily on a sequential basis. That will come back down in Q3, I would expect actually overall OpEx to decline from Q2 to Q3 at this point in time.
componenttext: Sure, Bob. I'd say that a few one-time costs in Q2, especially in the G&A line, you saw that jumped pretty heavily on a sequential basis. That will come back down in Q3, I would expect actually overall OpEx to decline from Q2 to Q3 at this point in time. There's also a fair bit of variable comp in there as we outperformed in the first half of the year. Really nothing besides that.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps a little bit of a sort of a longer-term question. It seems like coming out of the Analyst Day, the focus was definitely on rolling out further cloud services, with the expectation that we will see some of those on additional products in the back h
componenttext: Perhaps a little bit of a sort of a longer-term question. It seems like coming out of the Analyst Day, the focus was definitely on rolling out further cloud services, with the expectation that we will see some of those on additional products in the back half of this year. So, I guess, the question is, are we on track for further cloud service rollouts? Is there anything kind of in the guide for those? And how should we think about that impacting results into 2017, maybe even just from a kind of mix shift and how revenues is recognized perspective?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Keith. This is David. Let me just take the guidance part of that question. Overall, I wouldn't say there's anything explicit in our guidance. However, implicitly, we are certainly talking about a model shift that we've seen gradually. For us, we're i
componenttext: Yes, Keith. This is David. Let me just take the guidance part of that question. Overall, I wouldn't say there's anything explicit in our guidance. However, implicitly, we are certainly talking about a model shift that we've seen gradually. For us, we're in the fortunate position where a lot of it is incremental to what we've already done. The CSP, for example, which is ratable coming out on the Workspace Services business, is addressing SMBs and other areas that our core products wouldn't have. That business is running about a $75 million ARR right now. When I look back at core Citrix cloud delivered services, ShareFile is clearly the biggest, but we've also rolled out new services around XenMobile. We deliver networking actually as a service. We have desktop and VDI and some of these other things that we are rolling out as new services. When you aggregate those together, that business is running at about a 30% clip, and it's generating an ARR of roughly $130 million per year. So when you put those 2 together, and we are sitting on over $200 million of annualized recurring revenue growing north of 30% right now. That's probably the best way to really frame out the shift that we've seen over the past couple of years versus a type of revenue model that you would've had historically. It will be a shift that continues. We're going to talk about this metric each and every quarter to give people more visibility into how that's moving. And when the time comes, not in fiscal year '16, when the time comes, we're going to be more aggressive in our shift in installed base or something that could have a material impact, we make sure we talk about that well in advance and communicate that explicitly as part of guidance.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add that Citrix cloud is overall, obviously, very significant transformative momentum that is building inside Citrix. We signaled the fact that we're all in into cloud at the Synergy event in May. We're working hard to solidify our roadma
componenttext: And I would just add that Citrix cloud is overall, obviously, very significant transformative momentum that is building inside Citrix. We signaled the fact that we're all in into cloud at the Synergy event in May. We're working hard to solidify our roadmaps and continue to deliver new services. We have some additional milestones later in this year. And most importantly, in January of 2017 that our kick-off with our partner community, where we're going to be articulating more detailed strategy and more detailed deliverables. But before this calendar year ends, we will have some very significant things to articulate to the channel and to the market in terms of our wins, in terms of the reference customers that are going onto Citrix cloud end-to-end and continuous alignment with Microsoft on the overall cloud delivery. So it's, I would say, from where we were early in the year, we've made huge progress. From what we announced at Synergy, we feel good at where we are on the delivery, and I would say overall, we are on track with this cloud transformation. And of course, as David mentioned, once we have specifics and details on the pace and updated guidance, we will certainly bring it up to you.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then maybe just one more, just very tactical question. Can you talk about some uneven macro out there? Any explicit impacts that you saw either on Q2 results or sort of how you're thinking about close rate in the pipeline coming specificall
componenttext: Excellent. And then maybe just one more, just very tactical question. Can you talk about some uneven macro out there? Any explicit impacts that you saw either on Q2 results or sort of how you're thinking about close rate in the pipeline coming specifically from Brexit?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, there's some uncertainty that comes from any ramp like that. And just like anyone else in business and anyone else in our industries, we see some modest impact of Brexit. But I don't -- I wouldn't characterize it as material. And for us,
componenttext: Well, obviously, there's some uncertainty that comes from any ramp like that. And just like anyone else in business and anyone else in our industries, we see some modest impact of Brexit. But I don't -- I wouldn't characterize it as material. And for us, the most important is to bring our execution in EMEA to the level of Americas. And I think that is the most important priority of ours, and that's what we're focused on in EMEA right now.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Rob Owens with Pacific Crest Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Rob Owens with Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, back to, I think, where we started with Walter a little bit on the license updates and maintenance. Help us with some of the puts and takes there. You mentioned you didn't get a renewal in the quarter, which would've made things look better. But wh
componenttext: David, back to, I think, where we started with Walter a little bit on the license updates and maintenance. Help us with some of the puts and takes there. You mentioned you didn't get a renewal in the quarter, which would've made things look better. But what do renewal rates look like overall? And then with regard to moving into the CSP Workspace Services in the cloud, help us with some of the puts and takes there, because you didn't really showing a big improvement in sequential deferred revenue despite the fact that your license revenue was up even for Workspace.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take the license update piece first. Yes, on a year-on-year basis, it was up about 3%. There was -- our single largest customer renewal that happens on an annual basis, it just slipped a little bit. And because of that, some chunk of revenue g
componenttext: Yes. Let me take the license update piece first. Yes, on a year-on-year basis, it was up about 3%. There was -- our single largest customer renewal that happens on an annual basis, it just slipped a little bit. And because of that, some chunk of revenue got deferred out of the quarter. That will come back in Q3. I'd say that's the only one real anomaly that's out there. The other 2 dynamics that I talked about earlier important to understand in terms of net new licenses and Workspace Services. And then, the underlying ARR of each individual customer contract below that. And that's a work we're doing to capture that multi-hundred million dollar opportunity by migrating everybody to maintenance offerings. So I think that's kind of the dynamic in there. I think from a full year, I would expect that license update and maintenance line to be growing, roughly 3% all in. The...

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then -- go ahead.
componenttext: Okay. And then -- go ahead.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, ask your question.
componenttext: Go ahead, ask your question.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say, and then secondarily, with regards to Europe shifting gears. You mentioned that you laid the groundwork there. What evidence do you have in terms of improvement? Is there improved bookings rates? When would you expect this to turn the co
componenttext: I would just say, and then secondarily, with regards to Europe shifting gears. You mentioned that you laid the groundwork there. What evidence do you have in terms of improvement? Is there improved bookings rates? When would you expect this to turn the corner? Because it was down obviously year-over-year but also down sequentially. Then APAC has been down for quite a while. So when can we expect some improvement on that front?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say, Europe is obviously an aggregation of a number of unique markets. I mean, obviously our largest being the U.K., and that's been the most challenged from an execution point of view. If we step back and we exclude U.K., it's masking a really s
componenttext: Yes, I'd say, Europe is obviously an aggregation of a number of unique markets. I mean, obviously our largest being the U.K., and that's been the most challenged from an execution point of view. If we step back and we exclude U.K., it's masking a really solid growth across a number of other regions in EMEA. So that's clearly our focus in terms of making that better. The same thing holds true for our Japan business. It's one of those areas that's been somewhat challenged, and we're in the process of working on execution there. And what we've seen in the U.S., I mean, the pattern works. We're having really good results there. We're just [indiscernible] to drive it around the rest of the world.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: So how soon should that pattern work? What's the expected timing for return?

componenttext: Well, we're working on it right now. And hopefully, you'll see results and let's make [ph] EMEA in the second half of the year. And that will be focused on the U.K. We'll probably talk a little bit more about it just because it is such a big market and it's been one that's been underperforming for us over the course of the first half of the year.

componenttext: On Workspace, can you just talk a little bit about the load single-digit organic growth? What you think you need to change to get that high single-digit organic growth?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we just have to keep executing. I mean, it's been a trend. It's been up into the right for a number of quarters now. We are seeing more growth in users than we are in actual revenue. Some of that is just a shift in the overall model towards term lic
componenttext: Well, we just have to keep executing. I mean, it's been a trend. It's been up into the right for a number of quarters now. We are seeing more growth in users than we are in actual revenue. Some of that is just a shift in the overall model towards term license, towards CSP, towards other things. Users have been growing in the mid-single digits for a couple of quarters now. I think that's a reflection of the work that we've done. And we're going to keep it at that. A number of things that Kirill talked about that we're doing from new cloud services, work with Microsoft, et cetera, more to come on that front. I think at this point, it's really just execution. We're going to continue the pattern that we've been on.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, just with the mid-single digit user growth, what's the discrepancy? Is it just you're just giving lower prices per user? What's happening there? And how does that -- does that wear off over time?
componenttext: And David, just with the mid-single digit user growth, what's the discrepancy? Is it just you're just giving lower prices per user? What's happening there? And how does that -- does that wear off over time?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's a different type of user. CSP, for example, it's one that we've talked about now for a couple of times. Those are monthly subscriptions, where our CSP partners are leveraging XenApp to deliver a cloud service. We build those on a monthly arrears
componenttext: No, it's a different type of user. CSP, for example, it's one that we've talked about now for a couple of times. Those are monthly subscriptions, where our CSP partners are leveraging XenApp to deliver a cloud service. We build those on a monthly arrears basis. That business is growing at about 35%. It generates a much higher user account. If you think about that in ARR terms, which is again, is an important metric that we're going to have to be talking more about, that business runs with an ARR of about $75 million a year right now, which is a material part of overall Workspace Service license. If I look at just other SaaS inside of that, the smaller services, those are obviously growing faster than the whole. So that's the primary disconnect you see between users and recognized revenue.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just a clarification from me. You just said, I guess, well first of all, how long does it take for that 25% of Workspace installed base to transition to ARR? And when you say product license revenue grew 1% year-over-year for this business, does th
componenttext: David, just a clarification from me. You just said, I guess, well first of all, how long does it take for that 25% of Workspace installed base to transition to ARR? And when you say product license revenue grew 1% year-over-year for this business, does that include the subscription transition to ARR? Because the subscription, as I think you just said, is in the product license line, isn't it?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the case of CSPs, yes, it's in the product license line. In the case of any cloud-delivered service, that shows up on the SaaS line. In terms of the installed base, we've got about 25% migrated. We have new products being delivered with, I guess, you c
componenttext: In the case of CSPs, yes, it's in the product license line. In the case of any cloud-delivered service, that shows up on the SaaS line. In terms of the installed base, we've got about 25% migrated. We have new products being delivered with, I guess, you could think about it as a holistic maintenance offering instead of a stand-alone Subscription Advantage contract. The difference from a customer point of view, and you can model this out, is think roughly 5 percentage points of revenue is the difference in pricing between one contract and the other. We're doing some things right now that will accelerate the installed base migration on the latter part of this year and into next year. At our Analyst Day, we identified a couple of hundred million dollar plus opportunity just within this installed base, and that's one of the areas that we'll be driving over the next few quarters. And you'll start to see the results early next year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And if I could follow up. NetScaler business for the fourth quarter in a row has shown really strong growth. I know you've been hesitant to call it this, but it's starting to really look like a secular trend. I mean, like a more consistent se
componenttext: Okay, great. And if I could follow up. NetScaler business for the fourth quarter in a row has shown really strong growth. I know you've been hesitant to call it this, but it's starting to really look like a secular trend. I mean, like a more consistent secular trend. It's always been a driver, but it's always been really lumpy. But it seems like -- I mean, should we -- and then, could we anticipate this being just a pretty consistent driver going forward? It could -- it has been for now several quarters.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I think that overall, we have continued to outgrow the market for a number of years now. The part of the business that is associated with build-out of public cloud and cloud services is the part that has been really outperforming over the last 4 qua
componenttext: John, I think that overall, we have continued to outgrow the market for a number of years now. The part of the business that is associated with build-out of public cloud and cloud services is the part that has been really outperforming over the last 4 quarters. And it's the area that we want to continue to be cautious about because it does have a higher concentration than the other many thousands of customers. And so we're going to -- we will continue to be conservative on our outlook. But as you'd imagine, we're doing everything we can to make sure that it is a repeating item. We just want to be clear with everyone that it is more volatile and it does go up and down. We've just been really fortunate to see 4 quarters in a row of great performance.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think it is certainly worth noting that secular trends are playing to NetScaler's continuous growth. Obviously, cloud build-out only continues. It is hard to predict, but it certainly has been continuing for the last 4 quarters. Whether it's going t
componenttext: And I think it is certainly worth noting that secular trends are playing to NetScaler's continuous growth. Obviously, cloud build-out only continues. It is hard to predict, but it certainly has been continuing for the last 4 quarters. Whether it's going to continue at the same pace, I tend to believe that it will it, but it's impossible to pin it down, and therefore, we're being conservative on that part of the business. But then, there are additional parts of NetScaler that we're really excited about. The fact that NetScaler is essentially the only pure software-defined ADC enables us to do truly unique things in that market, as evidenced by some wins last quarter. And of course, emerging SD-WAN part of NetScaler [indiscernible] very strongly. And we expect that to start providing some real material growth in '17 as that market evolves and matures. And we're certainly planning on talking about it when we'll provide overall guidance for 2017 in late October.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kirill, what areas or what use cases does the advantage of having pure software solutions sort of rise to the top?
componenttext: And Kirill, what areas or what use cases does the advantage of having pure software solutions sort of rise to the top?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's just flexibility and how you deploy it. It's the ability to deploy NetScaler as a darker container essentially, enabling sort of more of kind of left to right load-balancing in the DevOps scenario. It's the ability to deploy this technology in
componenttext: Well, it's just flexibility and how you deploy it. It's the ability to deploy NetScaler as a darker container essentially, enabling sort of more of kind of left to right load-balancing in the DevOps scenario. It's the ability to deploy this technology in a traditional appliance. It's the ability to deploy this technology as a virtual machine or in the cloud. And its ability to move from one to another and it's the ability to scale up or scale down, depending on the need. It's also the ability to innovate at a rapid pace, where essentially you don't need to replace your hardware in order to move up to new capabilities or increase your capacity. You just sort of enable new softer features to deliver it and to unlock it. Those are sort of top obvious benefits. And of course, not to mention, the pace of execution being more agile and really sort of embracing new requirements much faster by delivering it in a software fashion.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just discuss what you see as really core business use case drivers for the really -- for the year-over-year rebound in the U.S., particularly around Workspaces and XenApp. Is there some pent-up demand in the market? Or more sp
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just discuss what you see as really core business use case drivers for the really -- for the year-over-year rebound in the U.S., particularly around Workspaces and XenApp. Is there some pent-up demand in the market? Or more specifically, when you look at the CSP model, are you having customers making a transition of their existing licenses into an expansion through CSPs?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, let's just start with Citrix strategy. We're all about secure delivery of apps and data, and this is the top of mind of every organization, large and small. Security and cybersecurity playing such a strong -- it's just such a strong priorit
componenttext: Well, I think, let's just start with Citrix strategy. We're all about secure delivery of apps and data, and this is the top of mind of every organization, large and small. Security and cybersecurity playing such a strong -- it's just such a strong priority for everybody. And I would say that is the #1 most significant secular trends that drives the need for Citrix solution. And of course, Windows 10, Skype for Business that we already discussed are additional very important capabilities that people need to embrace and that people need to deploy Skype for Business at scale with Citrix. You can do it securely and you can do it reducing your overall support cost. And sort of the other thing that I would mention is with the engineering work that Citrix have been doing over the last few years, we're now uniquely positioned to deliver XenApp and XenDesktop, essentially application virtualization and desktop virtualization, on the same platform. And we're seeing quite a strong number of customers really wanting to do both on the same platform. And some of those who were using XenApp in the past now want to deploy DDI, and having the same platform and the same infrastructure really enable them to do it with ease using the same tools, using the same life cycle manager -- management, that's the trend. And perhaps, the final thing that I would mention that sort of sets the Americas apart from the rest of the geos, here in Americas, the team embraced vertical focus ahead of everyone else. And if you think about health care wins, most of them happened here in Americas. And if you think about financial sector and focus there, most of those wins actually happen in Americas as well. And yet again, we expect that playbook to now to be replicated across the world, and that gives us confidence in the future.

componenttext: No, there really has not. I mean, at this point, it's something that we have -- we pushed out just with this transaction ongoing. later in this year, we'll come back. We'll talk more about capital strategy and whatnot. But I think the anticipation is we've been very aggressive with share repurchase over the last several years. It's been our primary use of cash flow and will likely continue to be going forward.

componenttext: Yes, Jason. Yes, the guidance is reflective of a really good second half last year, but I wouldn't read into it at this point in time. componenttext: Are you currently exploring the app refactoring space? I know that [indiscernible], who was at Synergy, was working on the XenApp integration. Is that still in process? It seems like their capabilities could be pretty beneficial for -- especially legacy apps accessing with XenMobile?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Within XenMobile, we have a broad range of capabilities that enable customers to essentially take their legacy apps and deliver them through newer technologies. There also some very interesting things that are sort of being currently in the pilot mod
componenttext: Yes. Within XenMobile, we have a broad range of capabilities that enable customers to essentially take their legacy apps and deliver them through newer technologies. There also some very interesting things that are sort of being currently in the pilot mode coming out of our labs that would take legacy Microsoft Access applications and put them out on HTML5-enabled devices, which essentially, if you think about it, tens of millions of those Microsoft Access applications that are out there hidden in the coffers of large enterprises being essentially locked from being able to accessed from those modern devices. Now that value that is quite important for those customers is being unlocked through that technology. So there's a number of initiatives at play here. And I would say sort of our overall approach of helping customers blaze their path into the future. But most importantly, being focused on the future and focused on the cloud is what we're going to continue to execute, and there's a broad range of things sort of coming from both angles here.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
