headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Shannon, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to M
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Shannon, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Mr. Eduardo Fleites, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Fleites, you may begin your conference.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shannon. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's third quarter 2016 earnings presentation. Participating on the call will be Kirill Tatarinov, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David Henshall, Chief Operating
componenttext:
Thank you, Shannon. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's third quarter 2016 earnings presentation. Participating on the call will be Kirill Tatarinov, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David Henshall, Chief Operating Officer and Chief Financial Officer. This call is being webcast on Citrix Systems' Investor Relations website. The webcast will be posted immediately following the call.
Before we begin, I want to state that we have posted product specification and historical revenue trends related to our product groupings to our Investor Relations website.
I'd like to remind you that today's conversation will contain forward-looking statements made under the safe harbor provision of the U.S. securities law. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Obviously, these risks could cause actual results to differ from those anticipated. Additional information concerning these and other factors is highlighted in today's press release and in the company's filings with the SEC. Copies are available from the SEC or on the company's Investor Relations website.
Furthermore, we will discuss various non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC's Reg G. A reconciliation of the differences between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures discussed on today's call can be found at the end of today's press release and on the Investor Relations page of our website. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to David Henshall, our COO and CFO. David?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us today. We continue to show great results and overall execution from the operational initiatives that have been driving profitability, to the strength in product portfolio that's driving top line growth.
componenttext:
Thanks, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us today. We continue to show great results and overall execution from the operational initiatives that have been driving profitability, to the strength in product portfolio that's driving top line growth. We're focusing all of our energy on the core strategy of securely delivering apps and data, really setting the company up for sustainable profitable growth as we look forward. 
As you can see from the release, total revenue was up 3% year-on-year in Q3. Adjusted operating margin expanded to over 30%. Adjusted EPS was $1.32 per share, up 27% year-on-year, and we generated nearly $290 million in cash flow from ops. In total, we closed 49 $1 million-plus transactions, with particular strength in cloud, health care, technology and government verticals. There was also good balance across the portfolio, with more than half of these deals coming from Workspace Services, with the balance coming from networking. 
From a geographic perspective, when you exclude the GoTo businesses, revenue from the Americas was up 8%. APJ was flat, and the EMEA market declined about 4%. This performance is pretty consistent with the first half of the year. The Americas geo continues to drive significant growth across all product categories, while the other regions are seeing improving execution in many of our primary markets. 
Related to this, in Q3, we announced a leadership change in the APJ region and pending change in the U.K. And these things will help accelerate field restructuring into 2017. 
Next, I want to talk about Q3 results within our 3 primary businesses. Within Workspace Service business, which includes virtualization mobility, grew 5% total to $414 million, including a 5% year-on-year increase in product license revenue. This growth rate has been really moving up over the last 6 quarters and is a direct result of the focused strategy we adopted last year. As we've discussed a few times, there's a number of very specific initiatives that we're driving to accelerate growth in this area through much faster innovation, more verticalized solutions, integration of our unique assets across the portfolio and the reinvigoration of our channel partnerships. 
Just a couple of other dynamics that are worth noting. That includes the license revenue in the Americas geo, with across all of Workspace Services has accelerated last quarter. In Q3, this was up 18% year-on-year, and this is after already posting 16% license growth through the first half of the year. Much of this has been coming from mid-, large enterprise customers, often in verticals where security and compliance are major concerns. 
Additionally, we continue to grow our cloud service provider subscriptions, where partners are primarily utilizing XenApp to deliver cloud-based offerings to their customers. Overall, the Citrix Service Provider revenue grew about 30% to now have an ARR of over $75 million. 
Next, looking at Delivery Networking. Total revenue increased 1% in the quarter to $191 million. The largest part of this overall business, NetScaler ADC, posted license revenue growth of 5% against the strong Q3 a year ago. But impacting the results in the rest of the BU were the comps from the ByteMobile and cloud platform products that are part of the restructuring at the start of this year. 
Staying on NetScaler for a minute. I'll remind everybody that the business is essentially made up of 3 segments: cloud infrastructure and e-commerce; Citrix solution sales; and enterprise ADC. So within the quarter, demand from cloud and e-commerce continued to be really strong, consistent with what we've seen over the last 5 quarters. This segment, which is made up of roughly 200 different customers in the quarter, contributed about 40% of NetScaler product sales. The solution-attached segment represented 15% of the mix, with a number of app and mobile opportunities that included networking as part of an overall Citrix solution was up modestly from a year ago. And then enterprise ADC was the remaining 45% of the mix. All in, we sold over 1,600 networking customers during the period, with 1/3 of those being net new to Citrix. 
And finally, our SaaS-delivered revenue was up 9% to $207 million in the quarter. The contribution from the GoTo business was $173 million. And as far as the merger between GoTo and LogMeIn, we received U.S. antitrust approval in September and continue to expect this to close in the Q1 2017 time frame. 
When you look at just the cloud-based services that are part of core Citrix, we delivered $35 million in total revenue, growing 28% in the quarter. The bulk of this is coming from ShareFile, our secure data platform, with the other new offerings addressing workspaces and service needs for our customers. So clearly, we continue to see a shift in the way products are being consumed by customers, evolving slowly towards a more ratable model. So when you include revenue that is being generated from the Citrix Service Provider program, plus our own cloud-based services and the annual term license, the aggregate ARR is now over $225 million, growing very rapidly. 
So turning to operations. We've driven a lot of efficiencies in the company over the past 6 quarters and continue to do so in Q3. The actions across the business were designed to generate permanent expense reductions while reallocating investments to those areas that will drive profitable growth in the future. In Q3, adjusted operating margin was over 30%. This is up more than 400 basis points from last year. We're clearly operating well ahead of our stated goal of reaching 30% full year margins in 2017. 
The focus on leverage has also helped increase our cash flow profile for the company. Q3 cash flow from operations was a record $288 million. And over the trailing 12 months, we've generated a total of $1.14 billion in cash from ops, and this is up 21%. 
As you start to model fiscal 2017, I want to point out that historically, about 80% to 90% of cash flow from operations can be attributed to core Citrix business, with the remainder coming from GoTo. Exiting Q3, we had nearly $2.5 billion in cash and investments on the balance sheet, which is up sharply from last quarter. Over the last several years, our stated target has been to utilize half of free cash flow for capital return, a level which, frankly, we've regularly exceeded. As you know, this program has been on hold due to the pending separation of the GoTo business. So once that's completed, we intend to restart our programmatic capital return, and we'll talk definitively about those plans once the transaction is closed. 
Before I wrap up, let me talk about our current outlook and expectations for the remainder of the year. Our growth strategy and operational programs are clearly working. We're happy with the results, and we're confident in our plans for the balance of the year and looking into 2017. At the same time, we're going to continue our conservative outlook, given the pending GoTo merger with LogMeIn and the significant revenue upside we posted in Q4 of last year. That said, we're increasing our assumptions for Q4 and the full year. So for 2016, we now expect consolidated revenue between $3.4 billion and $3.41 billion and adjusted EPS of $5.18 to $5.20 this year. This represents revenue for core Citrix to be in the range of $2.71 billion to $2.72 billion or roughly 3.5 -- or excuse me, 2.5% to 3% growth, when you exclude the GoTo business. 
With respect to 2017, we're just finishing up our planning cycle, which is very normal for this point in Q4. At this stage, we still expect the GoTo merger to be completed in Q1 '17, so we're completely focused on the ongoing business at core Citrix. We're feeling good about the continued improvement in results, in the new product cycles and the early returns from Citrix cloud. We're also making the GoTo market capacity investments that should drive additional growth next year, particularly in the second half of 2017. Therefore, we're currently modeling 2017 full year revenue growth of 3% to 4% for core Citrix and adjusted operating margins of 32% to 33%. 
So now I'd like to turn it over to Kirill to give further color on the quarter and our focus areas looking forward. Kirill?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and hello and welcome, everyone. I'm obviously very pleased with our results, clearly demonstrating how our renewed focus is resonating in the marketplace. We're seeing growth in all of our core areas of business, most importantly in our
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and hello and welcome, everyone. I'm obviously very pleased with our results, clearly demonstrating how our renewed focus is resonating in the marketplace. We're seeing growth in all of our core areas of business, most importantly in our Workspace Services business, showing growth for the second consecutive quarter. 
Our efforts in accelerating product innovation and improving operational processes are working. And the progress on cultural transformation that defines us in the company will continue to power us forward. We're seeing improved stability in our workforce and incredibly strong employee engagement as evidenced by very strong results and participation in our recent global employee survey. 
Specific to our field organization, through these improvements, we now have approximately 100 more quota-carrying reps since our restructuring about a year ago. Our America sales team continues to fire on all cylinders with consistently strong execution quarter after quarter. And with the leadership changes we have implemented in APJ and more change upcoming in EMEA, we see great opportunity to replicate what's working so strongly in the Americas. 
Our vision is clear. Our strategy is crisp, and our execution has improved dramatically. We now have had 5 straight quarters of continuous operating improvement. 
A few additional comments on our solution areas. There's a big story this quarter, of course, Workspace Services or our Xen family. It's exciting to see this core part of our business delivering 5% year-over-year increase in license revenue. I'm encouraged by sales energy and tremendous product innovation in this area. After 2 quarters of solid growth, this is clearly not a fluke or just a blip on the radar. This is an exciting change deliberately driven by the strongest, highly differentiated products and much-improved competitive edge. 
Additionally, in September, we delivered XenApps and Desktop 7.11, a major release featuring day 1 support for Windows Server 2016, management innovations and user experience enhancements. We also acquired NorthScale, greatly complementary technology that adds extra capabilities in the user environment management and adds very smart workspace performance optimization techniques, unmatched in the industry. 
We saw more than 650 competitive wins in virtual client computing this quarter, and our win rate has been consistently improving. Specifically, one of the nation's largest grocery retail and supply chain services companies chose XenDesktop for VDI delivery to support their retail corporations, thanks to our partnership with Microsoft. 
And another major win against the top competitor in the space, one of the world's largest insurance providers chose to leverage XenDesktop to enable the efficient upgrade to Windows 10 on more than 20,000 desktops, also driven by our unique support for Skype for Business. 
We continue to see more customers choosing our entire portfolio due to stronger-than-ever product integration. For example, in a dual competitive win, a top clinical teaching hospital in the Netherlands is rethinking their Workspace Services end-to-end, chose Citrix Workspace Suite against both the virtualization competitor and the networking competitor, so they can implement a full coherent solution for hospital workplace innovation. 
Moving on to network delivery business. As David mentioned, we saw good growth in the core ADC area, with a 5% year-over-year increase from the already strong Q3 in 2015. On the product innovation front, we released a major update to NetScaler SD-WAN. We continue to be very encouraged by growth in that area. This update featured more advanced routing, simple deployment and unrivaled security capabilities. We also released NetScaler support for the fifth standard, a testament to our commitment to security in the U.S. federal government. And we released NetScaler CPX, a free developer version of NetScaler in a container, that allows for rapid deployment methodologies such as DevOps. It's a clear indicator of our team's focus on new technologies and increased innovation. 
We saw more than 500 competitive wins in the network delivery space globally, including a major African mobile communications company, a major international electronics company and a global technology company. All of which are using NetScaler to ensure high network availability, resilience and security in their services. 
On to data delivery. As with previous quarters, ShareFile continued to prove itself as a growing force in the Enterprise file, sync and share market, growing 25% year-over-year. We continue to drive rapid product innovation and expand ShareFile functionality in target industries, adding more workflows and cloud connectors. We're starting to see increased traction of ShareFile outside of the United States, where it's still the strongest, and in the larger Enterprise segment. Specifically, Daimler AG, one of the largest and well-known producers of premium cars and manufacturers of commercial vehicles, chose Citrix ShareFile to improve large file exchange across their organization, and it will help them reduce storage costs and support business departments when dealing with big amounts of data. 
On to the industry trends. Cybersecurity, bring-your-own-device phenomenon, cloud adoption and Microsoft refresh cycle all served as catalysts to our business in Q3. We saw a strong demand for our solutions to support organizations' initiatives to secure their data, applications and networks. This is particularly evident in highly regulated industries, including financial services and health care, which had more than a dozen large deals this quarter, as David mentioned. 
We also had several defense ministries and government agencies around the world choosing Citrix to address security concerns, the cybersecurity being the #1 concern for enterprises of all sizes and governments around the world. It is becoming increasingly evident that Citrix solutions are indeed one of the strongest defenses against potential endpoint device and perimeter attacks. 
Moving on to our progress in the cloud. This was a tremendous quarter in our cloud transformation. While it's still in early progress, the momentum is building, with wins coming from businesses of all sizes. Highlighting just a few examples. Hilti, a well-known provider of worldwide leading-edge technology for international construction professionals, has partnered with us to drive their cloud transformation and enable a bring-your-own-device policy for employees through Citrix cloud. Columbia University and another major Ivy League school both chose Citrix cloud to assist in their transition and reduce infrastructure costs and IT support needs. Citrix cloud overall is really starting to shine. 
A couple of remarks on our partnerships. This quarter, we saw a major step forward in our stronger-than-ever relationship with Microsoft. As you may recall, earlier this year, we had announced an elevated and more strategic partnership with Microsoft and now I'm happy to report that it's starting to bear fruit. We're seeing good alignment of our teams in the field, bringing those joint wins I previously mentioned. 
Also in August, Microsoft announced that they would transitioning out of Azure RemoteApp, and Citrix XenApp was designated as the destination for Azure RemoteApp customers. We're creating a clear migration path for Azure RemoteApp customers that want to use all of XenApp's capabilities. This announcement served as a continued vote of confidence that Citrix is clearly the right partner for future success to deliver more workloads on Azure and more adoption of Windows 10 and Office 365. 
As to our broader partner channel, the momentum is continuing to grow. And while we have nearly 50 $1 million-plus deals in Q3, the ShareFile sales coming from the mid-market is increasing, a clear signal that our strategy to expand in the mid-market is working and that our partner channel is more vibrant than ever. 
Just last week, we hosted our top partners in the Americas who gave us tremendous feedback on our mutual progress. 
And last but certainly not least, last month, we held our Annual Industry Analyst event, where we had the opportunity to share our vision, strategy and core messaging. The feedback was remarkable. I previously shared the confidence I heard from our customers and partners, and now hearing such positive reinforcement in our direction and focus from industry analysts was truly encouraging. Our strategy and overall positioning was very well-received, proving to me that we're on the right path. 
As I mentioned, with highly differentiated products, we have stepped up our competitive edge, and it is paying off. We're taking share in all our core areas of business. Overall, I feel very enthusiastic about the business and look forward to closing out the year strong and starting 2017 with Citrix being better and stronger than ever. 
Thank you, and we look forward to your questions.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

componenttextpreview: Kirill, a question for you. The Workspace growth rate of 5% was the best we've seen since, I'm looking back here at Q1 2014. You mentioned some of the strengths already. How confident are you that we are kind of -- could you go a little bit deeper into wh
componenttext: Kirill, a question for you. The Workspace growth rate of 5% was the best we've seen since, I'm looking back here at Q1 2014. You mentioned some of the strengths already. How confident are you that we are kind of -- could you go a little bit deeper into what drove that growth? And how confident are you there, kind of that -- kind of a number that you can kind of deliver in the future as well?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question. And obviously, we're incredibly excited with the continuous strength in this core part of our business. This is the second quarter, and 5% growth in license is truly remarkable. As I mentioned, it is driven by tremendous stre
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question. And obviously, we're incredibly excited with the continuous strength in this core part of our business. This is the second quarter, and 5% growth in license is truly remarkable. As I mentioned, it is driven by tremendous strength in our product. We've just simply never had such a strong technology, and the team has done a remarkable job innovating on this. 7.9 release coming out, at about the Synergy conference in May, it was very strong and it's driving tremendous adoption. And we just made it even stronger with 7.11 release and with a small tuck-in acquisition of NorthScale. I think it's also fair to say that virtual client computing, in many cases, is viewed as sort of one of the core parts in cybersecurity efforts that everybody is driving. And we're seeing it from regulated industries. We're seeing it from the governments. We certainly see that trend driving the business forward. And I expect that only to continue and only to accelerate. And last but not least, we're in the midst of a very significant refresh cycle in Microsoft environments, driven by Windows 10 adoption and the recent introduction of Windows Server 2016. And I think also coupled with Office 365 and the broad adoption and unique support that we have for Skype for Business, that will continue to be a very significant growth catalyst. So very encouraged by what we saw in Q3 and certainly feel very enthusiastic and bullish about future prospects in this core part of our business.

Is there something that's changing in that regard either from features that you put in the new release of the product or something you're seeing in the market that's different than what you've had in the past?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there are a lot of things that's happening in the markets, and I think the overall awareness of cybersecurity is escalating quite dramatically. Even in the last presidential debate, we heard about cybersecurity. I think it's for the first ti
componenttext: Well, I think there are a lot of things that's happening in the markets, and I think the overall awareness of cybersecurity is escalating quite dramatically. Even in the last presidential debate, we heard about cybersecurity. I think it's for the first time in history, and I think it's certainly served as a call to action to many. And it's just a continuous escalation that we see, from attackers being hobbyists a few years ago, to organized crime, to now rouge governments and cyber terrorists. This is certainly a major threat that everybody's feeling and everybody's experiencing. And people are truly starting to see virtual client computing, our core business, as one of the major defenses. And many people realize that essentially virtualizing their device may be one of the only ways they can truly secure the data and secure the device. So certainly, secular trend is helping. From the product perspective, we definitely continue to amp it up across the portfolio. With NetScaler capabilities that were released in June, with updates to the entire NetScaler portfolio and NetScaler gateway serving as essentially conditional access, with multi-factor authentication that many customers are starting to deploy, with information rights management being introduced into ShareFile and with continuous improvement in our core business, XenApps and Desktop, certainly, from the product point of view, we have continued to drive improvement. But I would say, last but not least, it's the sort of overall awareness that we've been driving in the marketplace. And I think as I shared with you when I first joined 9 months ago, even when I was doing my due diligence on Citrix a year ago, what I discovered was that there's a whole lot more to Citrix than the world knows about. And in the last 6 months, most importantly starting with Synergy in May, we have delivered the driven awareness to make sure that the world actually understands what we stand for and what we have to offer. And the world actually understands that improving cybersecurity defenses is the most significant outcome that our customer gets from deploying Citrix solutions. So all combined, that's what we're seeing and that's why we're amplifying this, and that's why it's going to be so important on a go-forward basis.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kash Rangan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kash Rangan.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as it relates to Microsoft Windows 10 and Server 2016, Kirill, curious to get your thoughts on how this opens up new Office release with Citrix relative to the other OS releases we've had. And certainly, there's been cycles of desktop virtualization ad
componenttext: So as it relates to Microsoft Windows 10 and Server 2016, Kirill, curious to get your thoughts on how this opens up new Office release with Citrix relative to the other OS releases we've had. And certainly, there's been cycles of desktop virtualization adoption in the past. And I'm curious, what are the new opportunities that opened up for you in this cycle? And also, if you can just mention very briefly, what is it that you're specifically implementing in EMEA that we should expect better results from in 2017?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks. Great couple of questions. I think on Microsoft refresh cycle, it would be fair to say that all of us expect that Windows 10 adoption in the enterprise to go faster. And I think most people took a bit of a pause and took a bit more time to do
componenttext: Yes. Thanks. Great couple of questions. I think on Microsoft refresh cycle, it would be fair to say that all of us expect that Windows 10 adoption in the enterprise to go faster. And I think most people took a bit of a pause and took a bit more time to do proof of concepts that were largely taking place in the spring. But now we're seeing adoption, and now we're seeing broad adoption in the enterprise and also that's what our friends at Microsoft is sharing with us. And as in the past, in major Microsoft refresh cycles, Citrix gets the benefit. As I mentioned, some major, major clients are deploying Windows 10 through VDI mechanisms, and that's tremendously helpful. We're now in the sort of final phases to implement Windows 10 VDI on Azure, which is coming in just the next short few months, and that will serve as additional catalyst. But certainly, our partnership with Microsoft and overall rate of adoption of Windows 10 is strong and it's accelerating, and we're really excited about it. On Windows Server 2016, this is the best server release ever that Microsoft had. And we're seeing good momentum. We expect strong adoption. I think if you read analyst reports about Windows Server adoption, sort of, obviously, in addition to all the rapid move to the cloud and to Azure, today, the majority of Windows Servers run Windows Server 2008, so their major refresh cycle is coming. And we believe that Windows Server 2016 will be right there and we'll be right there with it since we have supported it from day 1 when it was released.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the EMEA steps, if you don't mind.
componenttext: And the EMEA steps, if you don't mind.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: On EMEA, I think it's a transformation on leadership. We're in the final phases of addressing a couple of open positions in Northern Europe in particular. And we look forward to reporting on sort of upcoming leadership changes in that area and particularl
componenttext: On EMEA, I think it's a transformation on leadership. We're in the final phases of addressing a couple of open positions in Northern Europe in particular. And we look forward to reporting on sort of upcoming leadership changes in that area and particularly strong results. I would say that just like in many other companies we all profiled, there are obvious microeconomic factors that, I believe, impacted our performance in that region. I did have an opportunity to spend time in the EMEA region past summer and had a chance to get introduced to the team and see where we're making strong progress. The service reassurance, that's in Central and Eastern Europe, and in Germany, we have a strong leadership team and we have great execution. And we know precisely what needs to do. We have the model that's working very well in the Americas. We're going to replicate it in EMEA. And I think it's -- it represents good upside in my view.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karl Keirstead.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karl Keirstead.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've got a couple for Dave and I'll ask one at a time. David, on the margins, up, call it, 400 basis points year-over-year. You said your core operating margin guide for '17 higher than the prior guidance of 30%. So all good. I guess I'm asking a how long
componenttext: I've got a couple for Dave and I'll ask one at a time. David, on the margins, up, call it, 400 basis points year-over-year. You said your core operating margin guide for '17 higher than the prior guidance of 30%. So all good. I guess I'm asking a how long this party can last type of question, and maybe the way I'll phrase it is how close we are to the point where perhaps driving growth acceleration becomes a little bit more important than showing margin upside?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, Karl. I'd say that at the beginning of the year, we were talking a lot about, about restructuring and certain initiatives, and we have transformed that over the last couple of quarters just into the way we run the business. We've got an ongoing fo
componenttext: Got it, Karl. I'd say that at the beginning of the year, we were talking a lot about, about restructuring and certain initiatives, and we have transformed that over the last couple of quarters just into the way we run the business. We've got an ongoing focus on efficiencies and just getting better at everything we do. And that will translate into 2 ways. One is the margin you see; and then two is our ability to reinvest a lot of the savings, if you will, back into things that will drive growth. I'd say that the team is much more focused on driving growth into the future that margins because we're building that muscle just kind of in the ongoing operations of the company. As you mentioned, we're up a better part of 800 basis points over 2 years. There's still a number of specific projects in flight, those that have a longer tail, whether it's real-estate-related or procurement or those types of things that will continue to generate permanent savings. And as you saw on our prelim guidance for '17, we do think that there's a lot more opportunity to run the business at even more efficient levels than we are today. We're going to keep driving those. But I also think that you'll hear us talk much more about growth going forward because we're building a business around profitable growth, and that's the focus of the execution.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And that helps. And then maybe as my follow-up, a balance sheet question. David, your long-term deferred revenue growth has been really solid in the last 4 quarters, up 15%, 20%. But in the third quarter just reported, up 12%. Not a big deal, but
componenttext: Got it. And that helps. And then maybe as my follow-up, a balance sheet question. David, your long-term deferred revenue growth has been really solid in the last 4 quarters, up 15%, 20%. But in the third quarter just reported, up 12%. Not a big deal, but is there any story there that you could pass on to us around the long-term DR v sale?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No story. I think that if you look at our deferred revenue profile over the last many years, you tend to see Q1 and Q4 being the -- or excuse me, Q2 and Q4, the quarters where it goes up. Q1 and Q3, it just kind of dips down. It's just the cycle of th
componenttext: No. No story. I think that if you look at our deferred revenue profile over the last many years, you tend to see Q1 and Q4 being the -- or excuse me, Q2 and Q4, the quarters where it goes up. Q1 and Q3, it just kind of dips down. It's just the cycle of the business. So I would expect that to pop pretty heavily in Q4 this year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Ashley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Ashley.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I was going to follow up on the initial 2017 guidance. I realize it's, I'm not going to call it preliminary, but that it is high level at this point. Do have any color around what kind of expectations we might have for the products sectors of Worksp
componenttext: Dave, I was going to follow up on the initial 2017 guidance. I realize it's, I'm not going to call it preliminary, but that it is high level at this point. Do have any color around what kind of expectations we might have for the products sectors of Workspace Services or Delivery Networking, how we might think about their growth rate in '17?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, we're not going to guide to at that level right now. But just to talk about that a little bit more, everything that Kirill mentioned earlier in terms of the momentum around the Xen family business, that's just pure execution. And the other thing th
componenttext: Steve, we're not going to guide to at that level right now. But just to talk about that a little bit more, everything that Kirill mentioned earlier in terms of the momentum around the Xen family business, that's just pure execution. And the other thing that we've talked about is that there is an ongoing subscription component of that, the Citrix Service Provider business that I mentioned, which is largely Xen family. That's up to about $75 million ARR, growing at 30%. So we're addressing both more and more incremental efficiencies at the higher end of the market and also programs like CSP, which are just net new, largely targeting SMB and some mid-market. So it's coming from a number of different factors, and we feel like that momentum can continue. In terms of networking, there's really 3 big segments of that business as everyone knows. It's primarily around the secular trend towards cloud and e-commerce and SaaS providers. We're doing extremely well in that business, and we'll continue to expand the base. The attached motion, where today represents about 15% of the mix, that's been a function of what's been going on in the last 5 years around Workspace Services. So as that business reaccelerates, we'll just have many more opportunities to go on attach. And then third, around the part that we just termed core enterprise ADC, that's probably our single biggest capacity add from a go-to-market standpoint in '17. We've been ramping that up really last quarter, and we'll finish that up in Q4 time frame. But by the end of next year, we'll probably have a 20% increase in networking capacity across the board. So while it's largely a second half story, it's an area that we believe that we can continue this trend of taking share each and every year. We just need to be involved in more places where our customers are. And so that's just a little contextual flavor around the business. But in terms of overall guidance, just to reiterate, this year, the core business is doing about 2.5%, 3% growth. Our prelim guidance for next year is to actually accelerate that to 3% to 4%, and we think we can do that at a higher-margin structure.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could share with us how you're thinking about the opportunity changing for VDI. We've heard a lot about the price point due to hyper-converged coming down over the last year or so and an uptick in demand as a result. But I want
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could share with us how you're thinking about the opportunity changing for VDI. We've heard a lot about the price point due to hyper-converged coming down over the last year or so and an uptick in demand as a result. But I wanted to see how you see this trend re-evolving, if at all.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We certainly see sort of renewed energy from our customers and from our partners in the overall virtual client computing. And that involves VDI. That includes XenApp and virtual app, and frankly, it also includes XenMobile and that sort of complete e
componenttext: Yes. We certainly see sort of renewed energy from our customers and from our partners in the overall virtual client computing. And that involves VDI. That includes XenApp and virtual app, and frankly, it also includes XenMobile and that sort of complete end-to-end, end-user computing and device management. VDI is one segment that will be largely influenced by the refresh cycle of Windows 10. And we certainly see significant momentum and excitement building up there, and we feel that we're going to be strong beneficiaries of the trend. And we do have strong partnerships with hyper-converged appliance providers, and particularly, Nutanix, last quarter, announced increased partnership with XenServer. They're putting the XenServer in their appliances now, and they're working with us on the entire VDI stack on their appliance. It is primarily designed to serve mid-market, which is obviously going to play to our strategy of continued expansion in mid-market customers. And I view that as another net positive capital going forward.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up. Any change in the competitive dynamics there?
componenttext: And just a follow-up. Any change in the competitive dynamics there?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think change -- the change is very profound, and the change is very visible. We see it everywhere we go. With the strongest highly differentiated product and with dramatically improved competitive posture in the marketplace, we see increased win r
componenttext: Well, I think change -- the change is very profound, and the change is very visible. We see it everywhere we go. With the strongest highly differentiated product and with dramatically improved competitive posture in the marketplace, we see increased win rates. We see increased win rates in virtual client computing. We see increased win rates in networking. And that served as a very tremendous positive catalyst for the way our people feel and the way our partners feel and frankly, the way the industry feels about us. And I think it's really the case where success breeds more success.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, your gross margin improved for the first time in a few quarters. And all else equal, you'll get an additional lift next year without GoTo. But as part of your guidance, how are you thinking about overall gross margins in 2017?
componenttext: David, your gross margin improved for the first time in a few quarters. And all else equal, you'll get an additional lift next year without GoTo. But as part of your guidance, how are you thinking about overall gross margins in 2017?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we haven't actually guided to gross margin yet for '17. I think coming out of this quarter, we'll fill out the P&L, give it a little more granularity. But just, it's the same basic trends in Q3 that we've seen over the last couple of years. W
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we haven't actually guided to gross margin yet for '17. I think coming out of this quarter, we'll fill out the P&L, give it a little more granularity. But just, it's the same basic trends in Q3 that we've seen over the last couple of years. We've talked for several years, if you remember, about a plateau somewhere around the mid-80s, and that's materialized. I think that as the software-based businesses continue to rebound and get stronger, that obviously provides some upward -- upper lift to margins at the same time. It will definitely be higher in '17. But if you remember, even our SaaS properties today maintain pretty healthy gross margins. So stay tuned, we'll talk more about it in 3 months.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And for Kirill, in the U.K., I know it may be a little difficult to parse just given some company-specific factors that are at play. But are you seeing any impact from Brexit?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And for Kirill, in the U.K., I know it may be a little difficult to parse just given some company-specific factors that are at play. But are you seeing any impact from Brexit?

componenttext: I think we saw some impact in Q2, actually towards the end of the quarter. I would say that right now, if there is some impact, it's not material.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Abhey Lamba.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Abhey Lamba.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I had a question on growth drivers in the Workspaces business. How are Microsoft products really helping your sales? Since customers on maintenance get upgraded for free, are you seeing mix improvement? Or mostly are just added for the products? Or is
componenttext: So I had a question on growth drivers in the Workspaces business. How are Microsoft products really helping your sales? Since customers on maintenance get upgraded for free, are you seeing mix improvement? Or mostly are just added for the products? Or is it kind of helping you attract new customers? If you can just share or talk about that a bit according to different Microsoft products, that would be helpful.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. Thanks so much. I think it's across the board. I would say, predominantly, it's existing customers expanding the usage. This is really the case of our unique capability in our support of Skype for Business and deployment of Skype for
componenttext: Yes, great question. Thanks so much. I think it's across the board. I would say, predominantly, it's existing customers expanding the usage. This is really the case of our unique capability in our support of Skype for Business and deployment of Skype for Business, that is we really see significant acceleration, in particular in the financial sector. And we are working with those customers. And since we have a unique technology, we obviously get to benefit from that. And I would say that part of the Microsoft relationship has been working incredibly well. And we've been in a unique position for at least a year now, and it sounds like we're going to stay in that unique position for at least another 6 months, if not more. And of course, Windows 10, I think it would be fair to say, when you look at the worldwide deployment of Windows desktops, approximately, if you're kind of trying to triangulate different analyst reports, approximately 10% of those deployments run virtualized. And obviously, as those currently get to move to the new version of Windows, they typically go with the more recent and more advanced SKU of server, of Citrix solutions. And at the same time, they usually expand their usage. And that's certainly something that we are starting to see, and we expect to see more of that as we go into 2017, which gives us increased confidence.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kirk Materne.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kirk Materne.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones, one for David and one for Kirill. David, I might have missed it when Karl asked the question, but I didn't catch the core margins for the business this quarter. I assume they're maybe a couple of hundred basis points ahead of the aggreg
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones, one for David and one for Kirill. David, I might have missed it when Karl asked the question, but I didn't catch the core margins for the business this quarter. I assume they're maybe a couple of hundred basis points ahead of the aggregate, but I was just wondering if you could give us any color on that. And then Kirill, regarding sort of your investment priorities as you head into fiscal '17, can you just talk about if there's anything where you guys would want to make increases? I know there's a big push around more direct sales on the networking side this year. Is there anything that sort of stands out to you from an investment perspective as we head into next year?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kirk. The first part of the question about margin. We haven't done a full breakout P&L yet. We'll complete that in the next month or so. But I know with the 30.3% for the consolidated business, would be at least 31% for the core business. So historic
componenttext: Yes, Kirk. The first part of the question about margin. We haven't done a full breakout P&L yet. We'll complete that in the next month or so. But I know with the 30.3% for the consolidated business, would be at least 31% for the core business. So historically, it's been somewhere around 150 bps higher than the consolidated number.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and on the investment side, obviously, David mentioned we are still in the final stages of our 2017 planning. But sort of to give you our preliminary view where we see investment priorities. In GoTo market, it is not only increasing direct selling ca
componenttext: Yes, and on the investment side, obviously, David mentioned we are still in the final stages of our 2017 planning. But sort of to give you our preliminary view where we see investment priorities. In GoTo market, it is not only increasing direct selling capacity that we have been driving through most of 2016 and we will continue in 2017, but it's also reinvigorating, in many cases, our partner channel and putting more energy in working with our partners. It served us well, and we now see early signals that it's working to add more breadth back into business and to expand in the mid-market, and we expect to do more of that. On the sort of product portfolio, if there's one most significant major transformation that is happening at Citrix right now, it is cloud transformation. We started it earlier this year. We've declared that we're all in on the cloud, and we're absolutely going to continue. And it is starting to serve us very well from an awareness perspective, from the engagement perspective with even our existing customers, who all want to run their entire infrastructures in the cloud at some point in the future. And for them to know that Citrix is going to be there with them serves as tremendous reassurance, and we're going to continue to give them more proof points of how strong we're going to be growing there and how we're going to become a leader in this emerging discipline of Workspace-as-a-Service. And perhaps, sort of on a couple of additional major trends that we're embracing and that you're going to start seeing us sort of be central to is Workspaces IoT. This is overall Internet of Things taking place at people's workplace. It's really a scenario where you can imagine everything around you in your office now has a certain amount of compute capacity and connected to the Internet and what magical things can you do there. Now Citrix, being essentially a workspace transformation company for the last 27 years, has amazing DNA to essentially take advantage of this secular technological trend and give people the ability to help their people work better and work differently. And we're already engaged with some of our partners, in the systems integrated community in particular, who are starting to see those scenarios, and we're very engaged with some of our larger customers, who are now sort of turning into early adopters of those workplace IoT approaches. So really exciting things happening in the industry, and with Citrix being truly back on our sort of innovation edge, we're very excited about being a participant in that.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Turits.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Turits.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael Turits. David and Kirill, 2 sort of related questions or kind of complementary questions on NetScaler. One, can you talk about how big the -- how big hyperscale was as a percentage of the customer base in terms of dollars this quarter and what the
componenttext: Michael Turits. David and Kirill, 2 sort of related questions or kind of complementary questions on NetScaler. One, can you talk about how big the -- how big hyperscale was as a percentage of the customer base in terms of dollars this quarter and what the outlook for that is? And the second question is how are customers deploying VPX in their public cloud deployment? And do you see that as completely additive or it's cannibalistic at this point?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. It's David. I'll take the first piece. In terms of hyperscale, they would fall within that segment that we talk about as cloud infrastructure and e-commerce. It's 40% of the mix last quarter. And then those what I would call hyperscale, it's
componenttext: Yes, Michael. It's David. I'll take the first piece. In terms of hyperscale, they would fall within that segment that we talk about as cloud infrastructure and e-commerce. It's 40% of the mix last quarter. And then those what I would call hyperscale, it's only a handful and that would represent part of that market. The trend continues, and I mean, the meta-trend around just capacity buildout is -- has been great. So that business, whereas it used to be 1 or 2 quarters per year, has been strong for 4 or 5 quarters in a row now. And that's one of the things that you see us lapsing really, really tough comps in Q3 and Q4 of last year. Expect that to continue. We always have pretty good visibility on a full year basis. The quarter-to-quarter is somewhat subject to just the needs and capacity buildout of the hyperscale. As we go into next year, as I mentioned a minute ago, I mean, part of the strategy is expanding that category so that you're touching, what I'd call, Tier 2 clouds as well as broader e-commerce providers and others as well as the capacity investments and attach motion for the other segments. So that's what's going on in overall -- on networking. As far as VPX, I mean, remind everybody that the most important element of NetScaler is the fact that it's a software product. It's deployed across a number of form factors, everything from fully virtualized data center appliances, all the way down through virtual appliances and even in the form factor of a container. And we get a lot of leverage by being able to utilize one code base across all those different use case scenarios. So VPX on a license count was probably the fastest growing in Q3, and that's just a function of broad distribution. You can use that in the cloud. You can use that in your own data center. You can use it as part of a networking fabric, if you will. And it's just having that base for us is what -- one of the things that we leverage from a differentiation point of view.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just going to add one comment on VPX. As David mentioned, our Citrix Service Provider segment is growing very, very nicely. And we see while we don't break out individual elements of what Citrix Service Providers deliver through their private -- thr
componenttext: I was just going to add one comment on VPX. As David mentioned, our Citrix Service Provider segment is growing very, very nicely. And we see while we don't break out individual elements of what Citrix Service Providers deliver through their private -- through their part in the cloud, we see the share of networking in that segment overall growing, and that's all driven by VPX. So I would say, in that respect, it is additive.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess my -- want to drill down on the CPX question, are customers deploying it in public cloud? And are they thinking about doing that versus adopting any load balance in that it could be offered by the public cloud vendors?
componenttext: Right. I guess my -- want to drill down on the CPX question, are customers deploying it in public cloud? And are they thinking about doing that versus adopting any load balance in that it could be offered by the public cloud vendors?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'm not sure we can make a generalization. There's not enough data. I will say that the fastest-growing part of NetScaler is that being consumed as a service out of Amazon Marketplace, Azure Marketplace, et cetera. So if that's specifically what you
componenttext: Mike, I'm not sure we can make a generalization. There's not enough data. I will say that the fastest-growing part of NetScaler is that being consumed as a service out of Amazon Marketplace, Azure Marketplace, et cetera. So if that's specifically what you're asking about, I'd say that we're definitely seeing that. And part of the strategy around CPX obviously is to address the DevOps community further upstream, when you're building applications before you deploy those into the cloud. So it's a little bit of both. It's still a small, small part of the overall business, but as I mentioned, it's probably the fastest-growing element.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Maguire.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ed Maguire.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the changing use scenarios around Office. Historically, a lot of your customers have used -- have run Office on XenApp, but with the migration to Office 365, does this change how your customers are using the Xen platform?
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the changing use scenarios around Office. Historically, a lot of your customers have used -- have run Office on XenApp, but with the migration to Office 365, does this change how your customers are using the Xen platform?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't see much material change on how they use the Xen platform. And majority of our customers use Office with Office expansions. They continue to run those expansions virtualized. We see many customers running their -- essentially their Exchange serve
componenttext: We don't see much material change on how they use the Xen platform. And majority of our customers use Office with Office expansions. They continue to run those expansions virtualized. We see many customers running their -- essentially their Exchange servers in Office 365, but we see lots of customers still preferring to use Office deployed on their desktops and on their laptops and their devices, which Office 365 wouldn't allow, and we continue to see enterprise IT preferring to run those applications virtualized from either their own data centers or from essentially Citrix running on public cloud. So I would say no material change. And I think, overall, Citrix and Microsoft working so closely together and Citrix being a prime delivery mechanism of virtualized application from Azure, I see that as a neutral to positive shift as those customers go to more cloud deployments.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Ed. I would just add one thing. I mean, if you think back to your question from 10 or 20 years ago, where remote access to e-mail was a primary use case for a lot of customers, that's changed dramatically over the years. And so when we look past some
componenttext: Hey, Ed. I would just add one thing. I mean, if you think back to your question from 10 or 20 years ago, where remote access to e-mail was a primary use case for a lot of customers, that's changed dramatically over the years. And so when we look past some of the really pressing use cases like security and whatnot, workforce mobilization is a broader topic. It's actually really a big deal right now. And that's not just thinking about 1 or 2 apps, but the entire infrastructure that allows every worker, regardless of where they reside, to effectively be mobile. And companies are doing that in pretty broad scale, both from an engagement standpoint, but probably more importantly, from a real estate consolidation point of view, and just ways to increase their density and immediately bring down costs. So that's just another phenomenon we're seeing.

Right now, as I mentioned a couple of times, total recurring is only about $225 million of the base. So if you want to talk specifically about CSP, that product license revenue grew about 5.4% sequentially from Q2 to Q3.

componenttext: I think the question is for David. Should we think about an increasing headwind on that license revenue line as we go into 2017 from a shift towards more subscription licenses and more subs amortizing off the balance sheet?

componenttext: No, not in 2017. I think this is more a '18 through '20 story. At this point in time, we do not expect it to have a material impact on the P&L. We have accounted for the modest uptake in our guidance. And I think as we get into the second half of next year, maybe at our analyst meeting, we can talk a lot more about how we'll look to accelerate those plans over the next several years, but not in the short term.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then maybe one for Kirill. On -- definitely a lot more to talk about security this quarter. Just on a going-forward basis, are we talking more about just a security use case or a core set of products that already are good for executing on a se
componenttext: Got it. And then maybe one for Kirill. On -- definitely a lot more to talk about security this quarter. Just on a going-forward basis, are we talking more about just a security use case or a core set of products that already are good for executing on a security use case? Or is this a shift in terms of productizing security more -- putting more sort of just security functionality and maybe into the ADC boxes or more discrete security functionality in terms of what you guys are delivering within Workspace Services that would require new functionality through M&A or organic development?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it is both. I'd say, most importantly, it's emphasizing the benefits that we're already delivering and we've just been hiding it for lack of a better word, being somewhat not as vocal explaining to people what benefits we're already bringing
componenttext: Well, I think it is both. I'd say, most importantly, it's emphasizing the benefits that we're already delivering and we've just been hiding it for lack of a better word, being somewhat not as vocal explaining to people what benefits we're already bringing through our solutions. That's first that I would stress and highlight. And that's what you saw, and we're actually seeing positive response from industry analysts when we explained what we were doing last month. The feedback was very positive, and you may have seen some of them written about it. I think the second is, we've continuously driven innovation in this area, across NetScaler, Xen family and ShareFile, addressing increasing needs of cybersecurity defenses in our existing customers and future customers. And of course, we continue to look to improve it and to do even more in the area of cybersecurity for our customers, both organically and inorganically as well.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, folks, I really want to thank you for joining us today. And thanks so much for following Citrix as we continue on our journey to making Citrix better than ever. Obviously, we've had a great, great quarter, and we're very proud of our transformation
componenttext: Well, folks, I really want to thank you for joining us today. And thanks so much for following Citrix as we continue on our journey to making Citrix better than ever. Obviously, we've had a great, great quarter, and we're very proud of our transformation and restructuring that we've driven so far and the results that we're able to share with you. Our operational rigor and our execution has certainly been very strong, and we'll continue to drive forward as we finish 2016 and enter 2017. It is truly exciting to see our hard work being validated by our results. It's really great to see the progress that the team is driving, and I think there is a huge additional opportunity in front of us across a broad portfolio of solutions, across a very motivated and engaged employee base, strong partner channel, great customers that love and support working with us. And we're really looking forward to the future, engaging with you in the coming weeks and months. And thank you yet again for joining us today.
